tgt_text.2793: Demetrius, who was now shut up like a wild beast in a trap, was driven to use force, overran the country, and fought several slight actions successfully with Seleukup.
tgt_text.2794: On one occasion he withstood a charge of scythed chariots, and routed the enemy, and he also drove away the garrison of one of the passes, and gained the command of the road to Syria.
tgt_text.2795: He now became elated by success, and perceiving that his soldiers had recovered their confidence, he determined to fight Seleukus for his kingdom.
tgt_text.2796: Seleukus himself was now in difficulties.
tgt_text.2797: He had refused Lysimachus's offer of assistance, through SUB­ picion, and he feared to engage with Demetrius in battle, dreading the effects of his despair and the sudden turns of his fortune.
tgt_text.2798: However, at this crisis Demetrius was seized by a disorder which nearly carried him off, and utterly ruined his prospects;
tgt_text.2799: for some of his soldiers deserted to the enemy, and some dispersed to their own homes.
tgt_text.2800: After forty days he was able to place himself at the head of the remaining troops, and with them marched so as to lead the enemy to suppose that he meant to return to Cilicia;
tgt_text.2801: but as soon as it was dark he started without any sound of trumpet in the opposite direction, crossed the pass of Amanus, and began to plunder the plain of Kyrrhestis.
tgt_text.2804: Seleukus made his appear­ ance, and pitched his camp hard by.
tgt_text.2805: Demetrius now got his men under arms in the night and started to surprise Seleukus, whose army expected no attack, and was for the most part asleep.
tgt_text.2806: When he was informed of his danger by some deserters he leaped up in terror, and began putting on his boots and shouting to his friends that a savage beast was coming to attack them.
tgt_text.2807: Demetrius, observing from the noise which filled the enemy's camp that they had notice of his attempt, quickly marched back again.
tgt_text.2808: He was attacked at daybreak by Seleukus, and gained some advantage by a flank attack.
tgt_text.2809: But now Seleukus himself dismounted, took off his helmet, and with only a small shield in his hand went up to the mercenary troops of Demetrius, showing himself to them and inviting them to join him.
tgt_text.2810: They knew that he had for a long time refrained from attacking them out of a wish to spare their lives, and not for the sake of Demetrius;
tgt_text.2811: and they all greeted him, saluted him as King, and joined his army.
tgt_text.2812: Demetrius, who had seen so many turns of good and ill fortune, felt that this blow was final.
tgt_text.2813: He fled towards the pass of Amanus, and with a few friends and attendants took refuge in a thick wood for the night, hoping to be able to gain the road to Kaunus and so to reach the sea, where he hoped to find his fleet assembled.
tgt_text.2814: But when he found that his party had not enough money to procure them pro­ visions even for one day, he was forced to adopt other plans.
tgt_text.2815: Soon, however, he was joined by Sosigenes, one of his friends, who had four hundred gold pieces in his belt, and with this treasure they hoped to be able to reach the sea, and started as soon as it grew dark to make their way over the mountains.
tgt_text.2816: But when they saw the enemy's watch-fires blazing all along the heights, they despaired of effecting their passage by that route, and returned to the place whence they had set out, diminished in numbers, for some had deserted, and greatly disheartened.
tgt_text.2817: When one of them ventured to hint that Demetrius ought to surrender himself to Seleukus, Demetrius seized his sword and would have made away with himself, but his friends stood round him, and at length talked him over into giving himself up.
tgt_text.2818: He sent a messenger to Seleukus, putting himself unreservedly in his hands.
tgt_text.2819: L. Seleukus, when he heard what had happened, said that it was his own good fortune, not that of Demetrius, which had saved Demetrius's life, and had given himself an opportunity of displaying his clemency and goodness as well as his other virtues.
tgt_text.2820: He at once sent for his ser­ vants and bade them construct a royal tent, and make every preparation for the reception of Demetrius in a mag­ nificent fashion.
tgt_text.2821: There was one Apollonides at the court of Seleukus, who had been an intimate friend of Demetrius, and Seleukus at once sent him to Demetrius, to bid him be of good cheer, and not fear to meet his friend and relative Seleukus.
tgt_text.2822: When the King's pleasure became known, a few at first, but afterwards the greater part of his followers, eagerly flocked to pay their court to Demetrius, who they imagined would become the second man in the kingdom.
tgt_text.2823: This ill-judged zeal of theirs turned the compassion of Seleukus into jealousy, and enabled mischief-makers to defeat his kindly intentions by warning him that as soon as Demetrius was seen in his camp all his troops would rise in mutiny against him.
tgt_text.2824: Apollonides had just reached Demetrius in high spirits, and others were arriving with wonderful stories about the goodness of Seleukus.
tgt_text.2825: Deme­ trius himself was just recovering his spirits after his dis­ aster, was beginning to think that he had been wrong in his reluctance to surrender himself, and was full of hope for the future, when Pausanias appeared with about a thousand horse and foot-soldiers.
tgt_text.2826: He suddenly surrounded Demetrius with these troops, separated him from his friends, and, instead of bringing him into the presence of Seleukus, conducted him to the Syrian Chersonese, where, though strongly guarded, he was supplied by Seleukus with suitable lodging and entertainment, and allowed to take the air and hunt in the royal park which adjoined his dwelling.
tgt_text.2827: He was permitted to associate with any of the companions of his exile whom he wished to see, and many polite messages were sent to him from Seleukus to the effect that as soon as Antiochus and Stratonike arrived, they would come to some amicable arrangement.
tgt_text.2829: Demetrius now despatched letters to his son, and to the commanders of his garrisons at Athens and Corinth, warning them not to pay any attention to any despatches which they might receive in his name, or even to his royal signet, but to regard him as practically dead, and to hold the cities in trust for his heir Antigonus.
tgt_text.2830: His son was much grieved at hearing of his father's capture, put on mourning, and sent letters to all the other kings, and to Seleukus himself, begging for his father's liberation.
tgt_text.2831: He offered to give up all the places which he still held, and even proposed to surrender himself as a hostage in place of his father.
tgt_text.2832: Many cities and princes supported his request, except Lysimachus, who offered to give Seleukus a large sum of money if he would put Demetrius to death.
tgt_text.2833: But Seleukus, who had always disliked Lysimachus, now regarded him with abhorrence as a savage villain, and still continued to keep Demetrius in captivity, under the pre­ text that he was waiting for the arrival of his son Antio- ChUB and Stratonike, that they might have the pleasure of restoring him to liberty.
tgt_text.2834: LI I. Demetrius at first bore up manfully against his misfortunes, and learned to endure captivity, taking exer­ cise as well as he could, by hunting in the park, and by running;
tgt_text.2835: but, little by little, he neglected these amuse­ ments, addicted himself to drinking and dicing, and thus spent most of his time;
tgt_text.2836: either in order to escape from the thoughts of his present condition by intoxication, or else because he felt that this was the life which he had always wished to lead, and that he had caused great suffering both to himself and to others by fighting by sea and land in order to obtain that comfort which he had now unex­ pectedly discovered in repose and quiet.
tgt_text.2837: What, indeed, is the object of the wars and dangers which bad kings endure, in their folly, unless it be this?
tgt_text.2838: although they not only strive after luxury and pleasure, instead of virtue and honour, but do not even understand in what real luxury and enjoyment consist.
tgt_text.2839: Be that as it may, Deme­ trius, after living in confinement in the Chersonese for three years, died of laziness, surfeit and over-indulgence in wine, in the fifty-fourth year of his age.-
tgt_text.2840: Seleukus was greatly blamed for the suspicions which he had enter­ tained about Demetrius, and greatly repented that he had not imitated the wild Thracian Dromichætes, who dealt so kindly and royally with Lysimachus when he had taken him prisoner.
tgt_text.2842: Even the funeral of Demetrius had an air of tragedy and theatrical display.
tgt_text.2843: His son Antigonus, as soon as he heard that the ashes of his father were being brought to him., collected all his fleet and met the vessels of Seleukus near the Cyclades.
tgt_text.2844: Here he received the relics in a golden urn on board of his own flagship, the largest of his fleet.
tgt_text.2845: At every port at which they touched the citizens laid garlands upon the urn, and sent deputies in mourning to attend the funeral.
tgt_text.2846: When the fleet arrived at Corinth, the urn was beheld in a conspicuous place upon the stem of the ship, adorned with a royal robe and diadem, and surrounded by armed soldiers of the king's body- guard.
tgt_text.2847: Near it was seated the celebrated flute-player Xenophantus, playing a sacred hymn;
tgt_text.2848: and the measured dip of the oars, keeping time to the music, sounded like the refrain of a dirge.
tgt_text.2849: The crowds who thronged the sea- shore were especially touched by the sight of Antigonus himself, bowed down with grief and with his eyes full of tears.
tgt_text.2850: After due honours had been paid to the relics at Corinth, he finally deposited them in the city of Demetrias, which was named after his father, and which had been formed by amalgamating the small villages in the neigh­ bourhood of Iolkos.
tgt_text.2851: Demetrius, by his wife Phila, left one son, Antigonus, and one daughter, Stratonike.
tgt_text.2852: He also had two sons named Demetrius, one, known as Leptus, by an Illyrian woman, and the other, who became ruler of Cyrene, by Ptolemais.
tgt_text.2853: By Deidameia he had a son named Alexander, who spent his life in Egypt.
tgt_text.2854: It is said, too, that he had a son named Korrhagus by Eurydike.
tgt_text.2855: His family retained the throne of Macedonia for many genera­ tions, until it ended in Perseus, during whose reign the Romans conquered that country.
tgt_text.2856: So now that we have brought the career of the Macedonian hero to a close, it is time for us to bring the Roman upon the stage.
tgt_text.2858: The grandfather of Antonius was the orator Antonius,* who belonged to the party of Sulla and was put to death by Marius.
tgt_text.2859: His father was Antonius, surnamed Creticus, † not a man of any great note or distinction in political affairs, but of good judgment and integrity, and also liberal in his donations, as one may know from a single instance.
tgt_text.2860: He had no large property and for this reason he was prevented by his wife from indulging his generous dis­ position.
tgt_text.2861: On one occasion when an intimate friend came to him who was in want of money, and Antonius had none, he ordered a young slave to put some water into a silver vessel and to bring it;
tgt_text.2862: and when it was brought, he moistened his chin as if he were going to shave himself.
tgt_text.2863: The slave being sent away on some other business, Antonius gave the cup to his friend and bade him make use of it , but as a strict inquiry was made among the slaves, and Antonius saw that his wife was vexed and intended to torture them one by one, he acknowledged what he had done and begged her pardon.
tgt_text.2865: His wife was Julia of the family of the Cæsars, a woman who could compare with the noblest and most virtuous of that day.
tgt_text.2866: She brought up her son Antonius, having married after his father's death Cornelius Lentulus,* who was one of the conspirators with Catilina and was put to death by Cicero.
tgt_text.2867: This appears to be the reason and the foundation of the violent enmity between Antonius and Cicero.
tgt_text.2868: Now Antonius says that even the corpse of Lentulus was not given up to them until his mother begged it of the wife of Cicero.
tgt_text.2869: But this is manifestly false, for no one of those who were then punished by Cicero was deprived of interment.
tgt_text.2870: Antonius was of distinguished appearance in his youth, but his friendship and intimacy with Curiof fell upon him, as they say, like some pestilence, for Curio himself was intemperate in his pleasures, and he hurried Antonius, in order to make him more manageable, into drinking and the company of women and extravagant and licentious expenditure.
tgt_text.2871: All this brought on him a heavy debt, and out of all bounds for his age, of two hun­ dred and fifty talents.
tgt_text.2872: Curio became security for all this, and when his father heard of it he banished Antonius from the house.
tgt_text.2873: Antonius for a short time mixed himself up with the violence of Clodius, the most daring and scandalous of the demagogues of the day, which was throwing every thing into confusion ;
tgt_text.2874: but becoming soon satiated with that madness and being afraid of those who were combining against Clodius, he left Italy for Greece and spent some time there, exercising his body for military contests and practising oratory.
tgt_text.2875: He adopted what was called the Asiatic style of oratory, which flourished most at that time, and bore a great resemblance to his mode of life, which was boastful and swaggering and full of empty pride and irregular aspiration after distinction.
tgt_text.2877: When Gabinius, ‡ a man of consular rank, was sailing for Syria, he endeavoured to persuade Antonius to join tho expedition.
tgt_text.2878: Antonius said that he would not go out with him as a private individual, but on being appointed commander of the cavalry, lie did go with him.
tgt_text.2879: In the first place he was sent against Aristobulus,* who was stir­ ring the Jews to revolt, and he was the first man to mount the largest of the fortifications;
tgt_text.2880: and he drove Aristobulus from all of them.
tgt_text.2881: lIe next joined battle with him and with the few men that he had put to flight the forces of Aristobulus, which were much more numerous, and killed all but a few;
tgt_text.2882: and Aristobulus was captured with his son.
tgt_text.2883: After this Ptolemæus † attempted to persuade Gabinius for ten thousand talents to join him in an invasion of Eygpt and to recover the kingdom for him;
tgt_text.2884: but most of the officers opposed the proposal, and Gabinius himself was somewhat afraid of the war, though he was hugely taken with the ten thousand talents;
tgt_text.2885: but Antonius, who was eager after great exploits and wished to gratify the request of Ptolemæus, persuaded Gabinius and urged him to the expedition.
tgt_text.2886: They feared more than the war the march to Pelusium, which was through deep sand where there was no water along the Ecregma ‡ and the Serbonian marsh, which the Egyptians call the blasts of Typhon,§ but which really appears to be left behind by the Red Sea|| and to be caused by the filtration of the waters at the part where it is separated by the narrowest part of the isthmus from the internal sea.
tgt_text.2887: Antonius being sent with the cavalry not only occupied the straits, but taking Pelusium also, a large city, and the soldiers in it, he at the same time made the road safe for the army and gave the general sure hopes of victory.
tgt_text.2888: Even his enemies reaped advantage from his love of distinction ;
tgt_text.2889: for when Ptolemæus entered Pelusium, and through his passion and hatred was moved to massacre the Egyptians, Antonius stood in the way and stopped him.
tgt_text.2890: And in the battles and the contests which were great and frequent, he displayed many deeds of daring and prudent generalship, but most signally in encircling and surrounding the enemy in the rear, whereby he secured the victory to those in front, and received the rewards of courage and fitting honours.
tgt_text.2891: Nor did the many fail to notice his humanity towards Archelaus* after his death;
tgt_text.2892: for Antonius, who had been his intimate and friend, fought against him during his lifetime of necessity, but when he found the body of Archelaus, who had fallen, he interred it with all honours and in kingly fashion.
tgt_text.2893: He thus left among the people of Alexandria the highest reputation, and was judged by the Roman soldiers to be a most illus­ trious man.
tgt_text.2895: With these advantages he possessed a noble dignity of person;
tgt_text.2896: and his well-grown beard, his broad forehead and hooked noset appeared to express the manly character which is observed in the paintings and sculptures of Her­ cules.
tgt_text.2897: And there was an old tradition that the Antonii were Herakleidæ, being sprung from Anton, a son of Her­ cules.
tgt_text.2898: This tradition Antonius thought that he strength­ ened by the character of his person, as it has been observed, and by his dress.
tgt_text.2899: For on all occasions, when he was going to appear before a number of persons, he had his tunic girded up to his thigh, and a large sword hung by his side, and a thick cloak thrown round him.
tgt_text.2900: Besides, that which appeared to others to be offensive, his great boasting and jesting and display of his cups, and his sitting by the soldiers when they were eating, and his eating himself as he stood by the soldiers' table -it is wonderful how much affection and attachment for him it bred in the soldiers.
tgt_text.2901: His amorous propensities, too, had in them something that was not without a charm, but even by these he won the favour of many, helping them in their Jove affairs and submitting to be joked with good humour about his own amours.
tgt_text.2902: His liberality and his habit of gratifying the soldiers and his friends in nothing with a stinted or Sparing hand, both gave him a brilliant foundation for power, and, when he had become great, raised his power still higher, though it was in danger of being subverted by ten thousand other faults.
tgt_text.2903: I will relate one instance of his profusion.
tgt_text.2904: He ordered five-and-twenty ten thou­ sands to be given to one of his friends;
tgt_text.2905: this sum the Romans express by Decies.*
tgt_text.2906: But as his steward wondered thereat, and to show him how much it was, placed the money out, he asked as he was passing by, What that was.
tgt_text.2907: The steward replying that this was what he had ordered to be given, Antonius, who conjectured his trickery;
tgt_text.2908: said, "I thought a Decies was more:
tgt_text.2910: and therefore add to it as much more."V. Now these things belong to a later period.
tgt_text.2911: But when matters at Rome came to a split, the aristocratical party joining Pompeius who was present, and the popular party inviting Cæsar from Gaul, who was in arms, Curio, the friend of Antonius, † changing sides in favour of Cæsar, brought Antonius over;
tgt_text.2912: and as he had great influence among the many by his eloquence, and spent money lavishly, which was supplied by Cæsar, he got Antonius appointed tribune, and then one of the priests over the birds, whom the Romans call Augurs.
tgt_text.2913: As soon as An­ tonius entered on his office, he was of no small assistance to those who were directing public affairs on Cæsar's behalf.
tgt_text.2914: In the first place, when Marcellus the consul attempted to give to Pompeius the troops that were already levied, and to empower him to raise others, An­ tonius opposed him by proposing an order, that the col­ lected force should sail to Syria and assist Bibulus, who was warring with the Parthians, and that the troops which Pompeius was levying should not pay any regard to him:
tgt_text.2915: and, in the second place, when the Senate would not receive Cæsar's letters, nor allow them to be read, Antonius, whose office gave him power, did read them, and he changed the disposition of many, who judged from Cæsar's letters that he only asked what was just and reasonable.
tgt_text.2916: Finally, when two questions were proposed in the Senate, of which one was, whether Pompeius should disband his troops, and the other, whether Cæsar should do it, and there were a few in favour of Pompeius laying down his arms, and all but a few were for Cæsar doing so, Antonius arose and put the question, Whether the Senate was of opinion that Pom­ peius and Cæsar at the same time should lay down their arms and disband their forces.
tgt_text.2917: All eagerly accepted this proposal, and with shouts praising Antonius, they urged to put the question to the vote.
tgt_text.2918: But as the consuls would not consent, the friends of Cæsar again made other pro­ posals, which were considered reasonable, which Cato resisted, and Lentulus, who was consul, ejected Antonius from the Senate.
tgt_text.2919: Antonius went out uttering many im­ precations against them, and assuming the dress of a slave, and in conjunction with Cassius Quintus* hiring a chariot he hurried to Caesar ;
tgt_text.2920: and as soon as they were in sight, they called out that affairs at Rome were no longer in any order, since even tribunes had no liberty of speech, but every one was driven away and in danger who spoke on the side of justice.
tgt_text.2921: VI. Upon this Cæsar with his army entered Italy.
tgt_text.2922: Accordingly Cicero, in his Philippica, said that Helen- was the beginning of the Trojan war, and Antonius of the civil war, wherein he is manifestly stating a falsehood.
tgt_text.2923: For Caius Cæsar was not such a light person, or so easy to be moved from his sound judgment by passion, if he had not long ago determined to do this, as to have made war on his country all of a sudden, because he saw Antonius in a mean dress and Cassius making their escape to him in a hired chariot;
tgt_text.2924: but this gave a ground and specious reason for the war to a man who had long been wanting a pretext.
tgt_text.2925: He was led to war against the whole world, as Alexander before him and Cyrus of old had been, by an insatiable love of power and a frantic passion to be first and greatest:
tgt_text.2926: and this he could not obtain, if Pompeius was not put down.
tgt_text.2927: He came then and got possession of Rome, and drove Pom­ peius out of Italy;
tgt_text.2928: and determining to turn first against the forces of Pompeius in Iberia, and then, when he had got ready a fleet, to cross over to attack Pompeius, he entrusted Rome to Lepidus, who was prætor, and the forces and Italy to Antonius, who was tribune.
tgt_text.2929: Antonius forth­ with gained the favour of the soldiers by taking his exer­ cises with them, and by generally living with them, and making them presents out of his means ;
tgt_text.2930: but to everybody else he was odious.
tgt_text.2931: For owing to his carelessness he paid no attention to those who were wronged, and listened with ill-temper to those who addressed him, and had a bad repute about other men's wives.
tgt_text.2932: In fine, Cæsar's friends brought odium on Cæsar's power, which, so far as con­ cerned Cæsar's acts, appeared to be anything rather than a tyranny:
tgt_text.2933: and of those friends Antonius, who had the chief power and committed the greatest excesses, had most of the blame.
tgt_text.2935: However, upon his return from Iberia, Cæsar* over­ looked the charges against him, and employing him in war because of his energy, his courage, and his military skill, he was never disappointed in him.
tgt_text.2936: Now Caesar, after crossing the Ionian Gulf from Brundusium with a few men, sent his ships back, with orders to Gabinius f and Antonius to put the troops on board and carry them over quickly to Macedonia.
tgt_text.2937: Gabinius was afraid of the voyage, which was hazardous in the winter season, and led his army by land a long way about;
tgt_text.2938: but Antonius being alarmed for Cæsar, who was hemmed in by many enemies, repulsed Libo,‡ who was blockading the mouth of the harbour, by surrounding his gallies with many light boats, and embarking in his vessels eight thousand legionary soldiers he set sail.
tgt_text.2939: Being discovered by the enemy and pursued, he escaped all danger from them in consequence of a strong south wind bringing a great swell and tempestuous sea upon his gallies;
tgt_text.2940: but as he was carried in his ships towards precipices and cliffs with deep water under them, he had no hope of safety.
tgt_text.2941: But all at once there blew from the bay a violent south-west wind and the swell ran from the land to the sea, and Antonius getting off the land and sailing in gallant style saw the shore full of wrecks.
tgt_text.2942: For thither the wind had cast up the gallies that were in pursuit of him and no small number of them was destroyed;
tgt_text.2943: and Antonius made many prisoners and much booty, and he took Lissus, and he gave Caesar great confidence by coming at a critical time with so great a force.
tgt_text.2945: There were many and continuous fights, in all of which Antonius was distinguished:
tgt_text.2946: and twice he met and turned back the soldiers of Caesar, who were flying in dis­ order, and by compelling them to stand and to fight again with their pursuers he gained the victory.
tgt_text.2947: There was accordingly more talk of him in the camp than of any one else after Cæsar.
tgt_text.2948: And Cæsar showed what opinion he had of him ;
tgt_text.2949: for when he was going to fight the last battle and that which decided everything at Pharsalus,* he had the right wing himself, but he gave the command of the left to Antonius as being the most skilful and bravest officer that he had.
tgt_text.2950: After the battle Cæsar was proclaimed dictator, and he set out in pursuit of Pompeius, but he appointed Antonius master of the horse and sent him to Rome:
tgt_text.2951: this is the second office in rank when the dictator is.
tgt_text.2953: but if he is not, it is the first and almost the only one.
tgt_text.2954: For the tribuneship continues, but they put down all the other functionaries when a dictator is chosen.
tgt_text.2956: However Dolabella,t who was then a tribune, a young man who aimed at change, introduced a measure for the annulling of debts, and he persuaded Antonius,* who was a friend of his and always wished to please the many, to work with him and to take a part in this political measure.
tgt_text.2957: But Asinius and Trebellius gave him the contrary advice, and it happened that a strong suspicion came on Antonius, that he was wronged in the matter of his wife by Dolabella.
tgt_text.2958: And as he was much annoyed thereat, he not only drove his wife from his house, who was his cousin, for she was the daughter of Caius Antonius who was consul with Cicero, but he joined Asinius and resisted Dolabella.
tgt_text.2959: Dolabella occupied the Forum with the design of carrying the law by force, but Antonius, after the Senate had declared by a vote that it was needful to oppose Dolabella with arms, came upon him and joining battle killed some of the men of Dolabella and lost some of his own.
tgt_text.2960: This brought on Antonius the hatred of the many, and he was not liked by the honest and sober on account of his habits of life, as Cicero says, but was detested;
tgt_text.2961: for people were disgusted at his drunkenness at unseasonable hours, and his heavy expenditure, and his intercourse with women, and his sleeping by day, and walking about with head confused and loaded with drink, and by night his revellings and theatres and his presence at the nuptials of mimi and jesters.
tgt_text.2962: It is said indeed that after being present at the entertainment on the marriage of Hippias the mime, and drinking all night, when the people summoned him early in the morning to the Forum, he came there still full of food and vomited, and one of his friends placed his vest under to serve him.
tgt_text.2963: Sergius the mime was one of those who had the greatest influence over him, and Cytheris† from the same school, a woman whom he loved, and whom when he visited the cities he took round with him in a litter;
tgt_text.2964: and there were as many attendants to follow the litter as that of his mother.
tgt_text.2965: People were also vexed at the sight of golden cups carried about in his excursions as in pro­ cessions, and fixing of tents in the ways, and the laying out of costly feasts near groves and rivers, and lions yoked to chariots, and houses of orderly men and women used as quarters for prostitutes and lute-players.
tgt_text.2966: For it was con­ sidered past all endurance that, while Caesar was lodging in the open field out of Italy, clearing up the remnant of war with great labour and danger, others, through means of Caesar's power, were indulging in luxury and insulting the citizens.
tgt_text.2968: These things appear also to have increased the dis­ order and to have given the soldiers licence to commit shameful violence and robbery.
tgt_text.2969: Wherefore, when Cæsar returned, he pardoned Dolabella;
tgt_text.2970: and being elected consul for the third time he chose not Antonius, but Lepidus for his colleague.
tgt_text.2971: Antonius bought the house of Pompeius when it was sold, but he was vexed when he was asked for the money;
tgt_text.2972: and he says himself that this was the reason why he did not join Caesar in his Libyan expedi­ tion, having had no reward for his former successes.
tgt_text.2973: How­ ever Cæsar is considered to have cured him of the chief part of his folly and extravagance by not allowing his excesses to pass unnoticed.
tgt_text.2974: For he gave up that course of life and turned his thoughts to wedlock, taking for his wife Fulvia, who had been the wife of the demagogue Clodius, a woman who troubled herself not about domestic industry or housekeeping, nor one who aspired to rule a private man, but her wish was to rule a ruler and command a general:
tgt_text.2975: so that Cleopatra was indebted to Fulvia * for training Antonius to woman-rule, inasmuch as Cleopatra received him quite tamed and disciplined from the commencement to obey women.
tgt_text.2976: However Antonius attempted by sportive ways and youthful sallies to make Fulvia somewhat merrier;
tgt_text.2977: as for example, on the occasion when many went to meet Caesar after his victory in Iberia, Antonius also went;
tgt_text.2978: but as a report suddenly reached Italy that Cæsar was dead and the enemy wei e advancing, he returned to Rome, and taking a slave's dress he came to the house by night, and saying that he brought a letter from Antonius to Fulvia, he was introduced to her wrapped up in his dress.
tgt_text.2979: Fulvia, who was in a state of anxiety, asked, before she took the letter, whether Antonius was alive;
tgt_text.2980: but without speaking a word he held out the letter to her, and when she was beginning to open and read it, he embraced and kissed her.
tgt_text.2981: These few out of many things I have produced by way of instance.
tgt_text.2983: When Cæsar was returning from Iberia* all the first people went several days' journey to meet him;
tgt_text.2984: but Antonius was specially honoured by Cæsar.
tgt_text.2985: For in his passage through Italy he had Antonius in the chariot with him, and behind him Brutus Albinus and Octavianus the son of his niece, who was afterwards named Cæsar and ruled the Romans for a very long time.
tgt_text.2986: When Cæsar was appointed consul for the fifth time, he immediately chose Antonius for his colleague, and it was his design to ab­ dicate the consulship and give it to Dolabella;
tgt_text.2987: and this he proposed to the Senate.
tgt_text.2988: But as Antonius violently opposed this, and vented much abuse of Dolabella and received as much in return, Cæsar, being ashamed of these unseemly proceedings, went away.
tgt_text.2989: Afterwards when he came to proclaim Dolabella, upon Antonius calling out that the birds were opposed to it, Cæsar yielded and gave up Dolabella, who was much annoyed.
tgt_text.2990: But it appeared that Caesar abominated Dolabella as much as he did Antonius;
tgt_text.2991: for it is said, that when some person was endeavouring to excite his suspicions against both, Cæsar said that he was not afraid of those fat and long-haired fellows, but those pale and thin ones, meaning Brutus and Cassius, who afterwards conspired against him and slew him.
tgt_text.2993: And Antonius without designing it gave them a most specious pretext.
tgt_text.2994: It was the feast of the Lykæa among the Romans, which they call Lupercalia,* and Cæsar dressed in a triumphal robe and sitting on the Rostra in the Forum viewed the runners.
tgt_text.2995: Now many youths of noble birth run the race, and many of the magistrates, anointed with oil, and with strips of hide they strike by way of sport those whom they meet.
tgt_text.2996: Antonius running among them paid no regard to the ancient usage, but wrapping a crown of bay round a diadem he ran to the Rostra, and being raised up by his companions in the race he placed it on Cæsar's head, intimating that he ought to be King.
tgt_text.2997: But as Cæsar affected to refuse it and put his head aside, the people were pleased and clapped their hands;
tgt_text.2998: then Antonius again offered the crown, and Cæsar again rejected it.
tgt_text.2999: This contest went on for some time, only a few of the friends of Antonius encouraging him in his pressing the offer, but all the people shouted and clapped when Cæsar refused;
tgt_text.3000: which indeed was surprising, that while in reality they submitted to be ruled over with kingly power they eschewed the name of King as if it were the destruction of their freedom.
tgt_text.3001: Accordingly Cæsar rose from the Rostra much annoyed, and taking the robe from his neck called out that he offered his throat to any one who would have it.
tgt_text.3002: The crown which was placed on one of his statues certain tribunes tore off, and the people fol­ lowed them with loud expressions of goodwill and clap­ ping of hands ;
tgt_text.3003: but Cæsar deprived them of their office.
tgt_text.3005: This confirmed Brutus and Cassius, and when they were enumerating the friends whom they could trust in the undertaking, they deliberated about Antonius.
tgt_text.3006: The rest were for adding Antonius to their number, but Trebonius opposed it;
tgt_text.3007: for he said that at the time when they went to meet Cæsar on his return from Iberia, and Antonius was in the same tent with him and journeyed with him, he tried his disposition in a quiet way and with caution, and he said that Antonius understood him, though he did not respond to the proposal, nor yet did he report it to Cæsar, but faithfully kept the words secret.
tgt_text.3008: Upon this they again deliberated whether they should kill Antonius after they had killed Cæsar;
tgt_text.3009: but Brutus opposed this, urging that the act which was adventured in defence of the laws and of justice must be pure and free from injustice.
tgt_text.3010: But as they were afraid of the strength of Antonius and the credit that his office gave him, they appointed some of the conspirators to look after him in order that when Cæsar entered the Senate house and the deed was going to be done, they might detain him on the outside in conversation about some matter and on the pretence of urgent business.
tgt_text.3012: This being accomplished according as it was planned and Cæsar having fallen in the Senate house, Antonius immediately put on a slave's attire and hid himself.
tgt_text.3013: But when he learned that the men were not attacking any one, but were assembled in the Capitol, he persuaded them to come down after giving them his son as a hostage;
tgt_text.3014: and he entertained Cassius at supper, and Brutus entertained Lepidus.
tgt_text.3015: Antonius having summoned the Senate spoke about an amnesty and a distribution of provinces among Brutus and Cassius and their parti zans, and the Senate ratified these proposals, and decreed not to alter anything that had been done by Caesar.*
tgt_text.3016: Antonius went out of the Senate the most distinguished of men, being considered to have prevented a civil war and to have managed most prudently and in a most statesmanlike manner circumstances which involved difficulties and no ordinary causes of confusion.
tgt_text.3017: But from such considera­ tions as these he was soon disturbed by the opinion that he derived from the multitude, that he would certainly be the first man in Rome, if Brutus were put down.
tgt_text.3018: Now it happened that when Cæsar's corpse was carried forth, as the custom was, he pronounced an oration over it in the Forum ;
tgt_text.3019: † and seeing that the people were powerfully led and affected, he mingled with the praises of Caesar coin­ miseration and mighty passion over the sad event, and at the close of his speech, shaking the garments of the dead, which were blood-stained and hacked with the swords, and calling those who had done these things villains and murderers, he inspired so much indignation in the men that they burnt the body of Cæsar in the Forum, heaping together the benches and the tables;
tgt_text.3020: and snatching burn­ ing faggots from the pile they ran to the houses of the assassins and assaulted them.
tgt_text.3022: For this reason Brutus and his party left the city, and the friends of Cæsar joined Antonius;
tgt_text.3023: and Caesar's wife Calpurnia trusting to him had the chief part of the treasures transferred to Antonius from her house, to the amount in all of four thousand talents.
tgt_text.3024: He received also the writings of Cæsar, in which there were entries made of what he had determined and decreed;
tgt_text.3025: and Antonius inserting entries in them, named many to offices just as he pleased, and many he named senators, and he restored some who were in exile and released others who were in prison, as if Cæsar had determined all this.
tgt_text.3026: Wherefore the Romans by way of mockery named all these persons Charonitæ,* because when they were put to the proof they had to take refuge in the memoranda of the deceased.
tgt_text.3027: And Antonius managed everything else as if he had full power, being consul himself, and having his brothers also in office, Caius as prætor and Lucius as tribune.
tgt_text.3029: While affairs were in this state, young Cæsar† arrived at Rome, being the son of the niece of the deceased, AS it has been told, and left the heir of his substance;
tgt_text.3030: and he was staying in Apollonia at the time of Cæsar's assas­ sination.
tgt_text.3031: He went forthwith to pay his respects to Antonius, as being his father's friend, and reminded him of the money deposited with him;
tgt_text.3032: for he had to pay to every Roman seventy-five drachmas, which Cæsar had given by his will.
tgt_text.3033: Antonius, at first despising his youth, said that he was not in his senses, and that being destitute of all sound reason and friends he was taking up the suc­ cession of Cæsar, which was a burden too great for him to bear;
tgt_text.3034: but as Cæsar did not yield to these arguments and demanded the money, Antonius went on saying and doing many things to insult him.
tgt_text.3035: For he opposed him in seeking a tribuneship, and when he was preparing to set up a golden chair of his father, as it had been voted by the Senate, he threatened to carry him off to prison, if he did not stop his attempts to win the popular favour.
tgt_text.3036: But when the youth, by giving himself up to Cicero and the rest who hated Antonius, by means of them made the Senate his friends, and he himself got the favour of the people and mustered the soldiers from the colonies,* An­ tonius being alarmed came to a conference with him in the Capitol, and they were reconciled.
tgt_text.3037: Antonius in his sleep that night had a strange dream ;
tgt_text.3038: he thought that his right hand was struck by lightning;
tgt_text.3039: and a few days after a report reached him that Cæsar was plotting against him.
tgt_text.3040: Cæsar indeed made an explanation, but he did not convince Antonius;
tgt_text.3041: and their enmity was again in full activity, and both of them roaming about Italy endeavoured to stir up by large pay the soldiers who were planted in the colonies, and to anticipate one another in gaining over those who were still under arms.
tgt_text.3043: Of those in the city Cicero had the greatest influence;
tgt_text.3044: and by inciting everybody against Antonius he finally persuaded the Senate to vote Antonius to be an enemy, and to send Caesar lictors and the insignia of a prætor, and to despatch Pansa and Hirtins† to drive An­ tonius out of Italy.
tgt_text.3045: They were consuls for that year;
tgt_text.3046: and engaging with Antonius near the city of Mutina, on which occasion Cæsar was present and fought with them, they defeated the enemy, but fell themselves.
tgt_text.3047: Many great difficulties befell Antonius in his flight;
tgt_text.3049: But it was the nature of Antonius to show his best qualities in difficulties, and in his mis­ fortune he was as like as may be to a good man ;
tgt_text.3050: for it is common to those who are hard pressed by straits to per­ ceive what virtue is, but all have not strength enough in reverses to imitate what they admire and to avoid what they do not approve;
tgt_text.3051: but some rather give way to their habits through weakness and let their judgment be de­ stroyed.
tgt_text.3052: Now Antonius in these circumstances was a powerful pattern to the soldiers, for though he was fresh from the enjoyment of so much luxury and expense, he drank foul water without complaining, and ate wild fruits and roots.
tgt_text.3053: Bark too was eaten, as it was said, and in their passage over the Alps they fed on animals that had never been eaten before.
tgt_text.3055: His design was to fall in with the troops there which Lepidus* commanded, who was considered to be a friend of Antonius and to have derived through him much advantage from the friendship of Cæsar.
tgt_text.3056: Having arrived there and encamped near, he found no friendly signs, on which he resolved to try a bold stroke.
tgt_text.3057: Antonius had neglected his hair and he had allowed his beard to grow long immediately after his defeat;
tgt_text.3058: and putting on a dark garment he approached the lines of Lepidus and began to speak.
tgt_text.3059: As many of the soldiers were moved at the sight and affected by his words, Lepidus in alarm ordered the trumpets to sound all at once and so to prevent Antonius from being heard.
tgt_text.3060: But the soldiers pitied the more, and t held communication with him by means of Lælius and Clodius, whom they secretly sent to him in the dress of women who followed the camp, and the messengers urged Antonius boldly to attack the lines, for there were many, they said, would undertake even to kill Lepidus, if he wished.
tgt_text.3061: Antonius would not consent to their touching Lepidus, but on the next day he began to cross the river with his army.
tgt_text.3062: Antonius entered the river first and ad­ vanced to the opposite bank, for he saw already many of the soldiers of Lepidus stretching out their hands to him and tearing down the ramparts.
tgt_text.3063: When he had entered and made himself master of all, he approached Lepidus with the greatest kindness, for he embraced him and called him father;
tgt_text.3064: and in fact he was master of all, but he continued to preserve to Lepidus the name and honour of an Imperator.
tgt_text.3065: This caused also Plancus Munatius to join him, for Plancus was at no great distance with a large force.
tgt_text.3066: Being thus raised anew to great power he crossed the Alps into Italy at the head of seventeen legions of infantry and ten thousand cavalry;
tgt_text.3067: besides this he left to guard Gaul six legions with Varius, one of his intimates and boon companions, whom they called Cotylon.
tgt_text.3069: Now Cæsar no longer cared for Cicero when he saw that he clung to liberty, but he invited Antonius through the mediation of his friends to come to terms.
tgt_text.3070: The three met together in a small islandt in the middle of a river and sat together for three days.
tgt_text.3071: All the rest was easily agreed on, and they distributed the empiret among them as if it were a p aternal inheritance, but the discus­ sion about the men who were destined to perish caused them most trouble, each claiming to get rid of his enemies and to save his relations.
tgt_text.3072: But at length surrendering to their passion against those whom they hated both the honour duo to their kinsmen and their goodwill to their friends, Cæsar surrendered Cicero to Antonius, and An­ tonius surrendered to him Lucius Cæsar, who was his uncle on the mother's side;
tgt_text.3073: Lepidus also was allowed to put to death his brother Paulus;
tgt_text.3074: but others say that Lepidus gave up his brother to Cæsar and Antonius, who required his death.
tgt_text.3075: I think nothing could be more cruel or savage than this exchange;
tgt_text.3076: for by exchanging murder for murder they equally destroyed those whom they sur­ rendered and those whom they put to death, but they acted more unjustly to their friends, whom they caused to die even without bearing them any hatred.
tgt_text.3078: After this settlement, the soldiers, who were around them, required that Caesar should strengthen their friendship by marriage, and should take to wife Clodia,* the daughter of Fulvia, the wife of Antonius.
tgt_text.3079: This also being agreed to, three hundred persons were by proscription put to death by them.t
tgt_text.3080: When Cicero was murdered, Antonius ordered the head to be cut off and the right hand, with which Cicero wrote the speeches against him.
tgt_text.3081: When they were brought, Antonius looked on them with delight and broke out a laughing several times through joy;
tgt_text.3082: then being satiated with the sight he ordered them to be placed above the Rostra in the Forum, as if he were insulting the dead, and not showing his own arrogance in his good fortune and abusing his power.
tgt_text.3083: His uncle Cæsar being sought and pursued fled for refuge to his sister, who, when the assassins were standing by and trying to force their way into her chamber, fixing herself at the door and spreading out her arms, called out repeatedly, " You shall not kill Cæsar Lucius, unless you kill me first, me the mother of the Imperator."
tgt_text.3084: By such her conduct she rescued and saved her brother.
tgt_text.3086: The dominion of the three was in most respects hateful to the Romans;
tgt_text.3087: but Antonius had most of the blame, as he was older than Cæsar, and had more influence than Lepidus, and threw himself without restraint into his former luxurious and intemperate habits as soon as he had shaken off all trouble about affairs.
tgt_text.3088: There was added to his general bad repute the hatred against him on account of the house that he inhabited, which had been the house of Pompeius Magnus, a man no less admired for his temperance and his orderly and citizenlike mode of life than for his three triumphs.
tgt_text.3089: For they were vexed to see his house generally closed to commanders, magis­ trates and ambassadors, who were insolently thrust from the doors, while it was filled with mimi and jugglers and drunken flatterers, upon whom was expended most of the money which was got by the most violent and harsh means.
tgt_text.3090: For the three not only sold the substance of those who were murdered, bringing false charges against their kinsmen and wives, and tried all kinds of imposts;
tgt_text.3091: but hearing that there were deposits * with the Vestal Virgins made both by strangers and citizens, they went and seized them.
tgt_text.3092: Now as nothing was enough for Antonius, Cæsar claimed to share the money with him;
tgt_text.3093: and they also distributed the army between them, and both went together into Macedonia to oppose Brutus and Cassius ;
tgt_text.3094: and they intrusted Rome to Lepidus.
tgt_text.3096: Crossing over the sea they commenced the campaign and encamped by the enemy, Antonius being opposed to Cassius, and Caesar to Brutus,t wherein no great deed was performed on the part of Cæsar, but it was Antonius who gained all the victory and had all the success.
tgt_text.3097: In the first battle, Caesar, being completely routed by Brutus, lost his camp and narrowly escaped from his pursuers;
tgt_text.3098: but, as he says in his Memoirs, he retired before the battle in consequence of one of his friends having had a dream.
tgt_text.3100: though some have written that Antonius was not in the battle, but came up after the battle to join in the pursuit.
tgt_text.3101: Pindarus, one of the faithful freedmen of Cassius, killed him at his request and order, for Cassius did not know that Brutus was victorious.
tgt_text.3102: After an interval of a few days they fought a second battle, in which Brutus being defeated killed himself, and Antonius carried off the chief credit of the victory, inasmuch as Cæsar was sick.
tgt_text.3103: Standing over the corpse of Brutus he upbraided it gently for the death of his brother Caius,* for Brutus had put Caius to death in Macedonia to revenge Cicero;
tgt_text.3104: but declaring that he blamed Hortensius more than Brutus for the murder of his brother, Antonius ordered him to be massacred on his tomb;
tgt_text.3105: and he threw over the body of Brutus his own purple cloak, which was of great value, and commanded one of his freedmen to look after the interment.
tgt_text.3106: He afterwards found out that this fellow did not burn the cloak with the corpse and that he had purloined a large part of the expenditure destined for the interment, whereon he put him to death.
tgt_text.3108: After this Cæsar went back to Rome, and it was supposed that he would not live long on account of his illness.
tgt_text.3109: Antonius crossed over into (Greece with a large army, intending to levy money in all the eastern provinces;
tgt_text.3110: for as they had promised to every soldier five thousand drachmae, they required more vigorous measures for raising money and collecting contributions.
tgt_text.3111: Towards the Greeks his conduct was neither unusual nor oppres­ sive at first, but his love of amusment led him to listen to the discourses of the learned and to the sight of games and religious solemnities;
tgt_text.3112: and in his decisions he was equitable, and was delighted at being called a Philhellen, but still more in being addressed as Philathenæus;
tgt_text.3113: and he made rich gifts to the city.
tgt_text.3114: The people of Megara also wishing to show him something fine, by way of rivalry with Athens, and requesting him to see the Senate-house, he went up and looked at if, and on their asking what he thought of it:
tgt_text.3115: " Small, it is true," he said, “ and yet all in decay.”
tgt_text.3116: He also caused the temple of the Pythian Apollo to be surveyed, as if he intended to repair it;
tgt_text.3117: for he made this promise to the Senate.
tgt_text.3119: Leaving Lucius Censorinus† over the affairs of Greece he crossed to Asia;
tgt_text.3120: and when he had touched the wealth there, and kings used to come to his door, and wives of kings vying with one another in their presents and their beauty let themselves be corrupted in order to win his favour, and while Cæsar at Rome was worn out with civil commotions and war, he enjoying perfect leisure and tranquillity was carried back by his passions to his usual habits of life, and Anaxenor t a lute-player and Xuthus a piper and Metrodorus a dancer, and other such rout of Asiatic theatrical folks who surpassed in impudence and shamelessness the pests from Italy, had crept in and managed his residence-it was past all bearing, for everything was waited on these extravagancies.
tgt_text.3121: For all Asia, like that city in Sophocles,§ at the same time was filled with incense burning, “ With pæans too 'twas filled and heavy groans.”
tgt_text.3122: Thus, when he was entering Ephesus, women clothed like Bacchæ, and men and boys equipped like Satyrs and Pans led the way;
tgt_text.3123: and the city was filled with ivy and thyrsi and psalteries and pipes and flutes, the people call­ ing him Dionysus, Giver of Joy and Beneficent.
tgt_text.3124: He was this, it is true, to some;
tgt_text.3125: but to the many Omestesll and Agrionius.
tgt_text.3126: For he took their property from well-born men and gave it to worthless men and flatterers;
tgt_text.3127: and certain persons got the substance of many who were still alive by asking for it as if they were dead.
tgt_text.3128: He gave the house of a citizen of Magnesia to a cook, who, as it is said, had distinguished himself by a single entertainment.
tgt_text.3129: Finally, when he was imposing a second contribution on the citizens, Hybreas* was bold enough in speaking on behalf of Asia to use these words, which were indeed such as the common folks would have in their mouths, but were not ill adapted to flatter† the vanity of Antonius, “ If thou canst take contributions twice in one year, thou canst also make for us summer twice and harvest-time twice but he concluded with these practical and bold words, that Asia had given twenty ten thousands of talents;
tgt_text.3130: and “if thou hast not had them, demand them of those who have received the money ;
tgt_text.3131: but if thou hast received and hast them not, we are undone."
tgt_text.3132: By these words he made a strong impression on Antonius, for he was ignorant of the greater part of what was going on;
tgt_text.3133: and not so much because he was indolent, as because in his simplicity he trusted those abc ut him.
tgt_text.3134: For there was in his character simplicity and slow perception;
tgt_text.3135: but when he did perceive his errors, there was strong repentance, and acknowledg­ ment to those who had been wronged, and excess both in the restitution that he made and the punishment that he inflicted.
tgt_text.3136: Yet he was considered to surpass the bounds of moderation rather in conferring favours than in punishing.
tgt_text.3137: His rudeness in mirth and bantering carried its own remedy with it;
tgt_text.3138: for a man might return him as good as he gave;
tgt_text.3139: and he took as much pleasure in being laughed at as in laughing at others.
tgt_text.3140: And this did him mischief in most things;
tgt_text.3141: for he could not believe that those who spoke so freely in jest, could flatter him in earnest, and so he was easily caught by praise, not knowing that some persons by mingling freedom of expression, like a sharpish sauce, with flattery, took away from flattery its nauseating insipidity, by their boldness and babbling over their cups striving to make their yielding in matters of business and their assent appear, not the way of persons who keep about a man merely to please him, but of those who are overpowered by superior wisdom.
tgt_text.3143: Such was the disposition of Antonius, upon which a crowning evil the love for Cleopatra supervening, and stirring up and maddening many of the passions that were still concealed in him and lying quiet, caused to vanish and utterly destroyed whatever of goodness and of a saving nature still made resistance in him.
tgt_text.3144: And he was captured in this fashion.
tgt_text.3145: When he was preparing for the Parthian war, he sent her orders to meet him in Cilicia to give an account of the charges made against her of supplying Cassius with much money and contributions for the war.
tgt_text.3146: Dellius,* who was sent, observing her person and marking her cleverness in speaking and her versatility, soon per­ ceived that Antonius would never even think of doing such a woman any harm, but that she would have the greatest influence with him ;
tgt_text.3147: and he applied himself to paying his court to her, and he encouraged the Egyptian, in the words of Homer,t to go to Cilicia bedecked in her best fashion and not to be afraid of Antonius, who was the most pleasant and kindest of generals.
tgt_text.3149: Dellius, and collecting from the proofs of her charms upon Caius Cæsar and Cnæus the son of Pompeius, she had hopes that she should more easily win over Antonius.
tgt_text.3150: For they knew her when she was yet a girl and inex­ perienced in affairs, but she was going to visit Antonius at an age in which women have the most brilliant beauty and their understanding has attained its perfection.
tgt_text.3151: Accord­ ingly she got together many presents and money and ornaments, such as one might suppose that she could bring from the greatness of her estate and the wealth of her kingdom, but she went to Cilicia relying chiefly on herself and the seductions and charms of her own person,XXVI.
tgt_text.3152: Though Cleopatra * received many letters of sum­ mons both from Antonius t and his friends, she so despised and mocked the man, that she sailed up the Cydnus in a vessel with a gilded stern, with purple sails spread, and rowers working with silver oars to the sound of the flute in harmony with pipes and lutes.
tgt_text.3153: Cleopatra reclined under an awning spangled with gold, dressed as Venus is painted, and youths representing the Cupids in pictures stood on each side fanning her.
tgt_text.3154: In like manner the hand­ somest of her female slaves in the dress of Nereids and Graces, were stationed some at the rudders and others at the ropes.
tgt_text.3155: And odours of wondrous kind from much incense filled the banks.
tgt_text.3156: Some of the people accompanied her im­ mediately from the entrance of the river on both sides, and others went down from the city to see the sight.
tgt_text.3157: As the crowd from the Agora also poured forth, Antonius was finally left on the tribunal sitting alone.
tgt_text.3158: A rumour went abroad that Venus was coming to revel with Bacchus for the good of Asia.
tgt_text.3159: Now Antonius sent to invite Cleopatra to supper, but she on her part said that he should rather come to her.
tgt_text.3160: Antonius accordingly, wishing to display some good nature and kindness, obeyed and came.
tgt_text.3161: He found a preparation greater than he expected, but he was most surprised at the number of the lights :
tgt_text.3162: for it is said that so many lights were hung down and shewn on all sides at once and arranged and put together in such in­ clinations and positions with respect to one another in the form of squares and circles, that of the few things that are beautiful and worthy of being seen this sight was one.
tgt_text.3164: On the following day when Antonius feasted her in turn he was ambitious to surpass her splendour and taste, but he was left behind and inferior in both, and in these very things he was the first to scoff at the coarse­ ness and rusticity of his own entertainment.
tgt_text.3165: Cleopatra, observing in the jests of Antonius much of the soldier and the unpolished man, adopted the same manner towards him freely and boldly.
tgt_text.3166: Now her beauty, as they say, was not in itself altogether incomparable nor such as to strike those who saw her;
tgt_text.3167: but familiarity with her had an irre­ sistible charm, and her form, combined with her persuasive speech and with the peculiar character which in a manner was diffused about her behaviour, produced a certain piquancy.
tgt_text.3168: There was a sweetness also in the sound of her voice when she spoke;
tgt_text.3169: and as she could easily turn her tongue, like a many-stringed instrument, to any lan­ guage that she pleased, she had very seldom need of an interpreter for her communication with barbarians, but she answered most by herself, as Ethiopians,* Troglodytes, Hebrews, Arabs, Syrians, Medes, Parthians.
tgt_text.3170: She is said also to have learned the language of many other peoples, though the kings her predecessors had not even taken the pains to learn the Egyptian language, and some of them had even given up the Macedonian dialect.
tgt_text.3172: Now she so captivated Antonius, that though his wife Fulvia was carrying on war at Rome against Cæsar on behalf of the interests of Antonius, and a Parthian army was hovering about Mesopotamia, of which the king's generals had named Labienus t Parthian governor, and they were about to enter Syria, he allowed himself to be carried off by her to Alexandria;
tgt_text.3173: and there staying and amusing himself like a young man who had leisure, he consumed and expended upon pleasure the most costly of all things, as Antiphon said, Time.
tgt_text.3174: They had a kind of company called Inimitable Livers;
tgt_text.3175: and they daily feasted one another, making an incredible profusion in their expenditure.
tgt_text.3176: Now Philotas of Amphissa,* a physi­ cian, used to relate to my grandfather Lamprias, that he was then in Alexandria learning his profession, and hav­ ing got acquainted with one of the royal cooks, he was persuaded by him, as was natural in a young man, to view the costliness and the preparation for the table.
tgt_text.3177: Accord­ ingly he was introduced into the kitchen, where he saw everything in great abundance, and eight wild boars roasting, which made him wonder at the number of the guests.
tgt_text.3178: Hereupon the cook laughed and said, the party at supper was not large, only about twelve ;
tgt_text.3179: but it was necessary that everything which was served up should be in perfection, which a moment of time would spoil.
tgt_text.3180: He said it might happen that Antonius should wish to sup immediately, and if it so happened, he might defer it by asking for a cup or by falling into some conversation;
tgt_text.3181: and accordingly, he continued, not one supper is prepared, but many, for the exact time is difficult to conjecture.
tgt_text.3182: This is what Philotas used to tell ;
tgt_text.3183: and in the course of time, as he related, he was among those who attended on the oldest son of Antonius, whom he had by Fulvia, and he supped with him with the rest of his companions, as a general rule, when he did not sup with his father.
tgt_text.3184: On one occasion there was a physician present who was brag­ ging greatly and much annoying the company at supper, but Philotas stopped him by a sophism of this kind :
tgt_text.3185: “If a man has fever in some degree, we must give him cold water ;
tgt_text.3186: but every man who has fever has fever in some degree ;
tgt_text.3187: we must therefore give cold water to every man who has fever."
tgt_text.3188: The man was confounded and put to silence, whereat the youth being pleased, laughed and said, "All this, Philotas, I give you, pointing to a table full of many large cups."
tgt_text.3189: Philotas acknowledged his in­ tended kindness, though he was far from thinking that a boy of his age had authority to make such a present;
tgt_text.3190: but after awhile one of the young slaves took hold of the cups and bringing them in a vessel bade him put a seal on it.
tgt_text.3191: As Philotas made objections and was afraid to take the things.
tgt_text.3192: " Why, you fool," said the man," do you hesitate ?
tgt_text.3193: Don't you know that the giver is the son of Antonius, and that he has permission to give so many things of gold ?
tgt_text.3194: If however you tae my advice, you will exchange the whole with us for a sum of money;
tgt_text.3195: for perchance the youth's father might call for some of the vessels, which are old and valued for their workmanship.”
tgt_text.3196: Such anecdotes as these my grandfather used to say that Philotas would oc­ casionally tell.
tgt_text.3198: But Cleopatra, by distributing flattery not, as Plato* says, in four ways, but in many ways, and by always adding some new pleasure and charm to whatever was either serious or mirthful, completely ruled Antonius, never leaving him by night nor by day.
tgt_text.3199: For she played at dice with him, and drank with him, and hunted with him, and was a spectator when he was exercising in arms, and by night when he was standing at the doors and windows of the common people and jesting with those within, she accompanied him in his rambles and freaks, in the dress of a female slave;
tgt_text.3200: for Antonius also used to dress himself in this style.
tgt_text.3201: Accordingly he would return home always well loaded with coarse abuse and sometimes with blows.
tgt_text.3202: With the greater part he was in no good credit;
tgt_text.3203: however the Alexandrines took delight in his extravagances, and joined in his follies without any lack of cleverness or humour, being pleased therewith and saying that Antonius put on the tragic mask to the Romans, but the comic mask to them.
tgt_text.3204: Now to relate the greater part of his follies would be mere trifling.
tgt_text.3205: How­ ever on one occasion when he was fishing and was vexed at his bad sport, Cleopatra also being present, he ordered the fisherman to dive under the water and secretly to fasten to the hook some fishes that had been already caught;
tgt_text.3206: and he pulled up two or three times, but not without being detected by the Egyptian.
tgt_text.3207: Pretending to admire, she spoke to her Mends and invited them to come as spectators on the following day.
tgt_text.3208: A number of them got into the fishing boats, and when Antonius had let down his line, she ordered one of her own men to anticipate him by diving to the hook and to fasten to it a Pontic salted fish.-
tgt_text.3209: Antonius thinking that he had caught something pulled up, on which there was, as was natural, great laughter, whereat Cleopatra said, " Give up the fishing-rud, Imperator, to us the kings of Pharos and Canopus;
tgt_text.3210: your sport is cities and kings and continents.
tgt_text.3212: While Antonius was spending his time in such trifles and extravagances, he was surprised by intelligence from two different quarters;
tgt_text.3213: from Rome, that Lucius his brother and Fulvia his wife, having first been at variance with one another and then having warred with Cæsar, were completely defeated and flying from Italy;
tgt_text.3214: the other intelligence was in no wise more favourable, which was that Labienus at the head of the Parthians had subdued Asia from the Euphrates and Syria as far as Lydia and Ionia.
tgt_text.3215: With difficulty then, like a man roused from sleep and a drunken debauch, he set out to oppose the Parthians, and advanced as far as Phœnice, but as Fulvia sent him letters full of lamentations be turned towards Italy, with two hundred ships.
tgt_text.3216: On this voyage he took up his friends who had fled from Italy, and learned from them that Fulvia had been the cause of the war, for she was naturally a busy and bold woman;
tgt_text.3217: but her hope was to draw away Antonius from Cleopatra, if their should be any dis­ turbance in Italy.
tgt_text.3218: It happened that Fulvia, who was Bailing to meet him, died at Sikyon of some disease, which rendered a reconciliation with Cæsar more easy.
tgt_text.3219: For when Antonius approached Italy, and Caesar was evidently not intending to make any charge against him, and Antonius was ready to fix on Fulvia the blame of what he was charged with, their friends would not let them come to any explanation of these grounds, but brought them both to terms and distributed the empire, making the Ionian gulf the boundary, and giving the eastern parts to Antonius and the western to Cæsar;
tgt_text.3220: Lepidus was allowed to keep Libya ;
tgt_text.3221: and it was settled that the friends of each in turns should be consuls, when it did not please them­ selves to be.
tgt_text.3223: This arrangement seemed to be good, but it required a stronger security, and fortune offered one.
tgt_text.3224: Octavia* was a sister of Caesar, older than Cæsar, but not by the same mother;
tgt_text.3225: for she was the daughter of Ancharia, but he was born afterwards of Atia.
tgt_text.3226: Cæsar was very greatly attached to his sister, and it is said she was a most admirable woman.
tgt_text.3227: Octavia was now a widow, for her husband Caius Marcellus had not long been dead.
tgt_text.3228: As Fulvia was dead, Antonius also was considered to be a widower;
tgt_text.3229: he did not deny that he had Cleopatra, but he did not admit that he had her as a wife, and he was still struggling in his judgment on this point against his love for the Egyptian.
tgt_text.3230: Everybody was proposing this marriage in the hope that Octavia, who in addition to great beauty possessed dignity of character and good sense, if she were united to Antonius and were beloved by him, as it was reasonable to suppose that such a woman must be, would be the conservation and cause of union between them in all respects.
tgt_text.3231: This being arranged between them, they went up to Rome where the marriage of Octavia was celebrated, though the law did not allow a woman to marry till ten months after her husband's decease, but the Senate in this case remitted the time by a decree.
tgt_text.3233: As Sextus* Pompeius was still in possession of Sicily and was ravaging Italy, and with his numerous piratical ships, of which Men as the pirate and Menekrates were commanders, had rendered the sea unsafe to vessels, and as he seemed to be in a friendly disposition towards Antonius, for he had received his mother when she had fled from Rome with Fulvia, it was resolved to come to terms with him also.
tgt_text.3234: They met at the promontory of Misenum and the mound, the fleet of Pompeius being anchored close by them, while the forces of Antonius and Caesar were arranged by the side of them.
tgt_text.3235: Having agreed that Pompeius should have Sardinia and Sicily on condition of keeping the sea clear of pirates and sending to Rome a certain quantity of grain, they invited one another to an entertainment.
tgt_text.3236: They cast lots on the occasion, and it was the lot of Pompeius to feast them first.
tgt_text.3237: Upon Antonius asking him where they should sup, " There," said he, point­ ing to the commander's ship of six banks of oars, “ for this is all the paternal residence that is left for Pompeius."
tgt_text.3238: This he said to reproach Antonius, who had the house that had belonged to the father of Sextus.
tgt_text.3239: Fixing his ship at anchor and making a kind of bridge from the promontory, he received them with a hearty welcome.
tgt_text.3240: When the banquet was at its height and jokes against Cleopatra and Antonius were plentiful, Menas the pirate approaching Pompeius said to him, so that the rest could not hear, “ Will you let me cut off the anchors of the ship and make you master not of Sicily and Sardinia, but of the Roman em­ pire?"
tgt_text.3241: Pompeius, on hearing this, considered with himself for a short time, and said, "You ought to have done it, Menas, without mentioning it to me:
tgt_text.3242: but now let us be satisfied with things as they are;
tgt_text.3244: Pompeius, after being feasted by Cæsar and Antonius in turn, sailed back to Sicily.
tgt_text.3246: After the settlement of affairs, Antonius sent forward Ventidius* into Asia to prevent the Parthians from advancing further, and, in order to please Cæsar, he was appointed priest of the former Cæsar;
tgt_text.3247: and everything else that concerned public affairs they transacted in common and in a friendly way.
tgt_text.3248: But their games of amusement caused annoyance to Antonius, as he always carried off therein less than Caesar.
tgt_text.3249: Now there was with Antonius a man skilled in divinations, an Egyptian, one of those who cast nativities, who, whether it was to please Cleopatra, or whether he said it in good faith, spoke freely to An­ tonius, saying that his fortune, though most splendid and great, was obscured by that of Cæsar, and he advised him to remove as far as possible from the young man:
tgt_text.3250: “ For thy daemon," he said, “ is afraid of the daemon of Cæsar, and though it is proud and erect when it is by itself, it is humbled by his dæmon when it is near, and becomes cowed."
tgt_text.3251: And indeed the things which were happening seemed to confirm the Egyptian;
tgt_text.3252: for it is said that when they were casting lots by way of amusement, in whatever they might happen to be engaged, and throwing dice, Antonius came off with disadvantage.
tgt_text.3253: They frequently matched cocks,* and fighting quails, and those of Caesar were always victorious.
tgt_text.3254: Whereat Antonius being annoyed, though he did not show it, and paying more regard to the Egyptian, departed from Italy, leaving the management of his affairs to Cæsar;
tgt_text.3255: and he took with him Octavia as far as Greece, there having been a daughter born to them.
tgt_text.3256: While he was spending the winter in Athens, he received intelligence of the first successes of Ventidius, who had defeated the Parthians in a battle, in which Labienus lost his life and Pharnapates, the most skilful of the generals of King Hyrodes.t
tgt_text.3257: On the occasion of this victory Antonius feasted the Greeks;
tgt_text.3258: and he acted as gymnasiarch for the Athenians, and leaving at home the insignia of his rank, he went forth with the rods of a gymnasiarch ‡ and the dress and white shoes;
tgt_text.3259: and he took the youths by the neck when he separated them.
tgt_text.3261: As he was going to set out for the war, he took a crown from the sacred olive, and in conformity to a certain oracle, he filled a vessel with water from the Clepsydra, and carried it with him.
tgt_text.3262: In the mean time Pacorus,* the king's son, with a large Parthian army again advanced against Syria, but Ventidius engaged with him in Cyrrhestica and put his army to flight with great loss;
tgt_text.3263: Pacorus himself fell among the first.
tgt_text.3264: This exploit, which was one of the most celebrated, gave the Romans full satisfaction for the defeat of Crassus, and again confined the Parthians within Media and Mesopotamia, after being defeated in three successive battles.
tgt_text.3265: Ventidius gave up all intention of pursuing the Parthians further, because he feared the jealousy of Antonius, but he visited those who had revolted and brought them into subjection, and be­ sieged Antiochus of Commagene† in the city Samosata.
tgt_text.3266: The king proposed to pay a thousand talents and to obey the order of Antonius, but Ventidius told him to send his proposal to Antonius;
tgt_text.3267: for he had now advanced near, and he would not allow Ventidius to make peace with Antio­ chus, because hb wished that this single exploit at least should bear his name, and that everything should not be accomplished by Ventidius.
tgt_text.3268: As, however, the siege was protracted, and the citizens, after despairing of coming to terms, betook themselves to a vigorous defence, Antonius, who was making no progress, but was ashamed and re­ pented of his conduct, was glad to make peace with An­ tiochus and to take three hundred talents;
tgt_text.3269: and after settling some trifling matters in Syria, he returned to Athens, and sent Ventidius to enjoy a triumph after be­ stowing on him the suitable decorations.
tgt_text.3270: Ventidius is the only Roman to the present time who has had a triumph over the Parthians;
tgt_text.3271: and he was a man of obscure birth, but the friendship of Antonius gave him the opportunity of doing great deeds, of which he made the best use, and so confirmed what was generally said of Antonius and Cæsar, that they were more successful as generals through others than of themselves.
tgt_text.3272: For Sossius* also, a legatus of Antonius, had great success in Syria;
tgt_text.3273: and Canidius,t who was left by Antonius in Armenia, defeated the Armenians and the kings of the Iberians and Albanians, and advanced as far as the Caucasus.
tgt_text.3274: All this success increased the name and the fame of the power of Antonius among the barbarians.
tgt_text.3276: Antonius being again irritated against Cæsar by certain calumnies, sailed to Italy with three hundred vessels;
tgt_text.3277: but as the people of Brundusium would not re­ ceive his fleet, he sailed round and anchored at Tarentum.‡
tgt_text.3278: There he sent Octavia, for she accompanied him from Greece, at her request, to her brother:
tgt_text.3279: she was then preg­ nant, and had already borne him two daughters.
tgt_text.3280: She met Cæsar on the way, and after gaining over his friends Agrippa and Mæcenas,§ she prayed him with much urgency and much entreaty not to let her become a most wretched woman after being most happy.
tgt_text.3281: For now, she said, all men turned their eyes upon her, who was the wife of one Imperator and the sister of another;
tgt_text.3282: “ but if the worse should prevail," she continued, “ and there should be war, it is uncertain which of you must be the victor and which the vanquished;
tgt_text.3283: but I shall be unfortunate both ways."
tgt_text.3284: Cæsar, being moved by these words, came in a friendly manner to Tarentum, and those who were present saw a most noble spectacle, a large army on land tranquil, and many ships quietly holding on the shore, and the meeting and friendly salutations of the two Imperators and their friends.
tgt_text.3285: Antonius gave an entertainment first, which Cæsar consented to for his sister's sake.
tgt_text.3286: It being agreed that Cæsar should give Antonius two legions for the Par­ thian war, and that Antonius should give Cæsar a hundred brazen-beaked vessels.
tgt_text.3287: Octavia, independently of what had been agreed, asked for her brother twenty light ships.
tgt_text.3288: from her husband, and for her husband a thousand soldiers from her brother.
tgt_text.3289: Accordingly, separating from one another, the one immediately engaged in the war against Pompeius,† being desirous to get Sicily;
tgt_text.3290: and Antonius, en­ trusting to Cæsar Octavia and his children by her and by Fulvia, crossed over to Asia.
tgt_text.3292: That great evil, which had long slept, the passion for Cleopatra, which appeared to be put to rest and to have been tranquillised by better considerations, blazed forth again and recovered strength as Antonius approached Syria.
tgt_text.3293: And finally (as Platot says of the stub­ born and ungovernable beast of the soul), kicking away everything that was good and wholesome, he sent Fonteius Capito to bring Cleopatra to Syria.
tgt_text.3294: On her arrival he gave and added to her dominions nothing small or trifling, but Phoenice, Cœle Syria, Cyprus, a large part of Cilicia, and further, that part of J udæa which produces the balsam, and all the part of Arabia Nabathæa which was turned towards the external sea.§
tgt_text.3295: These donations caused the Romans the greatest vexation;
