tgt_text.4759: Saying this he withdrew, putting them in great suspicion of the intended deed being known.
tgt_text.4760: In the meantime one came running from the house of Brutus and told him that his wife was dying.
tgt_text.4761: For Porcia, who was beside herself through thinking of what was going to be done, and unable to bear the weight of her anxiety, could scarce keep herself within doors, and at every noise and shout, like those possessed with bacchio frenzy, she would spring forth and question every one who came in from the Forum, what Brutus was doing, and was continually sending others out.
tgt_text.4762: At length, as the time began to be protracted, her bodily strength no longer held out, but she fainted and swooned away, her mind wandering by reason of her perplexity;
tgt_text.4763: and she could not reach her apartment before faintness and in­ describable alarm seized her, where she was sitting in the midst of her attendants, and her colour changed and her voice was completely choked.
tgt_text.4764: Her maids at this sight shrieked aloud, and as the neighbours quickly ran to the door, a report went forth and was given out abroad, that she was dead.
tgt_text.4765: However she quickly recovered and was herself again, and her women took care of her.
tgt_text.4766: Brutus was troubled, as was natural, by this report coming upon him;
tgt_text.4767: yet he did not desert the public interest, nor allow himself to be carried away by his feelings to his own domestic affairs.
tgt_text.4769: And now it was told that Cæsar was approaching, borne in a litter.
tgt_text.4770: For he had determined, in consequence of being dispirited by the sacrifices, to ratify nothing of importance at that time, but to put things off on the pretext of illness.
tgt_text.4771: When he had stepped out of the litter, Popilius Lænas hurried up to him, he who had a little before wished Brutus good luck and success, and he talked some time with Cæsar who was standing there and listen­ ing.
tgt_text.4772: The conspirators (for so we may call them) not hearing what he said, but conjecturing from their own suspicions that the conversation was a discovery of the plot, sunk in their spirits and looked at one another, by their countenances declaring to one another that they ought not to wait to be scized, but forthwith to die by their own hands.
tgt_text.4773: Cassius and some others had already laid their hands on the hilts of their daggers under their garments and were drawing them out, when Brutus observing in the attitude of Lænas the earnestness of a man who was asking a favour and not preferring an accusation, said nothing, because somany persons not of their party were mingled with them, but he encouraged Cassius by the cheering expression of his countenance.
tgt_text.4774: And soon after Lænas kissed Cæsar's right hand and withdrew, by which it was plain that he had :
tgt_text.4775: spoken with Cæsar about himself and some of his own concerns.
tgt_text.4777: The Senate having advanced to the exhedra, the conspirators surrounded Cæsar's chair, as if they designed to have a conference with him.
tgt_text.4778: And it is said that Cassius, turning his face to the statue of Pompeius, invoked him as if he could hear;
tgt_text.4779: and Trebonius having engaged Antonius in conversation at the door kept him out.
tgt_text.4780: As Cæsar entered, the Senate stood up, and as soon as he sat down, the conspirators in a body surrounded him, putting forward Tillius Cimber, one of their number, to supplicate for his brother who was an exile;
tgt_text.4781: and they all joined in the sup­ plication, laying hold of Cæsar's hands, and they kissed his breast and head.
tgt_text.4782: Caesar at first repulsed their in treaties, and then, as they did not intermit, he made a sudden attempt to rise up, on which Tillius, with both his hands, pulled Cæsar's garment down from the shoulders, and Casca first of all (for he stood behind him) drew his sword and drove it into Cæsar's body near the shoulders, but to no great depth.
tgt_text.4783: Caesar, laying hold of the handle, cried out aloud in the Roman language, " Villain Casca, what are you doing !" and Casca, addressing his brother in Greek, urged him to come to his aid.
tgt_text.4784: Cæsar being now assaulted by many, looked around with the intention of forcing his way through them, but when ho saw Brutus drawing his sword against him, he let loose his hold of Casca's hand, and wrapping his head in his garment he offered his body to the blows.
tgt_text.4785: The conspirators, who were all mingled in confusion, and using their numerous swords against Cæsar, wounded one another, so that even Brutus received a blow on the hand while he was taking part in the slaughter;
tgt_text.4786: and they were all drenched with blood.
tgt_text.4788: Cæsar having been thus killed, Brutus advanced into the midst wishing to speak, and he attempted to detain the Senate by encouraging them ;
tgt_text.4789: but the senators, through fear, fled in disorder, and there was shoving and confusion about the door, though no one pursued or pressed upon them.
tgt_text.4790: For it had been firmly resolved to kill no other than Cæsar, but to invite all to freedom.
tgt_text.4791: Now the rest, when they were deliberating about the deed, were of opinion that they should kill Antonius at the same time with Cæsar, as he was a man who aspired to monarchical power and was a violent man, and had got strength by his intercourse and familiarity with the army;
tgt_text.4792: and chiefly that to his natural haughtiness and daring temper he had added the dignity of the consulship, being then Cæsar's colleague.
tgt_text.4793: But Brutus opposed the design, first relying on grounds of justice, and next suggesting hopes of a change.
tgt_text.4794: For he did not despair that Antonius, a man of generous nature, a lover of honourable distinctions and fond of fame, when Cæsar was put out of the way, would join his country in seizing hold of freedom, and be led on by them through emulation to what was good.
tgt_text.4795: In this way Brutus saved Antonius;
tgt_text.4796: but in the then alarm Antonius changed his dress for plebeian attire and fled.
tgt_text.4797: Brutus and his partisans went to the Capitol, their hands stained with blood, and displaying their bare swords called the citizens to liberty.
tgt_text.4798: Now, at first, there were shouts, and the people running this way and that, as chance would have it, after the murder, increased the confusion;
tgt_text.4799: but as there was no more slaughter and no plundering of the things exposed for sale, both the senators and many of the plebeians took heart and went up to the conspirators to the Capitol.
tgt_text.4800: The multitude being assembled, Brutus spoke in a way to please the people and suitable to the cir­ cumstances ;
tgt_text.4801: and as the people commended him and called out for them to come down, the conspirators confidently descended to the Forum, the rest following with one an.
tgt_text.4803: but many of the persons of distinction putting Bru­ tus in the midst, of them, conducted him with great show from the Capitol, and placed him on the Rostra.
tgt_text.4804: At the eight of this the many, though a mingled body and pre­ pared to raise a tumult, were afraid, and they awaited the result in order and silence.
tgt_text.4805: When Brutus came forward they all listened to what he said ;
tgt_text.4806: but that the deed was not agreeable to all, they made evident when Cinna began to speak and to bring charges against Cæsar, by breaking out in passion and abusing Cinna, so that the conspirators returned to the Capitol.
tgt_text.4807: Brutus, fearing to be blockaded, then sent away the chief persons of those who had gone up with him, not thinking it right that, as they had no share in the blame, they should sustain a share in the danger.
tgt_text.4809: However, on the following day when the Senate met in the temple of Earth, and Antonius and Plancus * and Cicero had spoken about an amnesty and concord, it was resolved that the conspirators should not only have impu­ nity, but that the consuls should also propose a measure for conferring honours on them.
tgt_text.4810: They voted these things, and then separated.
tgt_text.4811: After Antonius had sent his son to the Capitol as a hostage, Brutus and the conspirators came down, and there were salutations and pressing of hands among all of them together.
tgt_text.4812: Antonius received Cassius and feasted him, and Lepidus entertained Brutus ;
tgt_text.4813: and the rest were entertained by others according to the intimacy or friendship that existed between them.
tgt_text.4814: At daybreak the senators met again, and in the first place they conferred honours on Antonius for having stopped the beginning of civil wars;
tgt_text.4815: in the second place, thanks were given to Brutus and his friends who were present, and finally distri­ butions of provinces.
tgt_text.4816: For to Brutus they decreed Crete, and to Cassius Libya, and to Trebonius Asia, and to Cimber Bithynia, and to the other Brutus Gallia on the Eridanus.
tgt_text.4818: After this a discussion arising about the will of Cæsar and his interment, and Antonius demanding that the will should be read, and that the body should be carried forth not secretly nor without due honours, so that this, too, might not irritate the people, Cassius violently opposed it, but Brutus gave way, wherein he was considered to have made a second mistake.
tgt_text.4819: For in sparing Antonius he incurred the imputation of strengthening against the conspirators a dangerous and irresistible enemy ;
tgt_text.4820: and as to the matter of the interment, in allowing it to take place in the way in which Antonius demanded, he was considered to have altogether made a mistake.
tgt_text.4821: For in the first place there being given by the will to every Roman seventy-five drachmæ,* and to the people there being left the gardens beyond the river, where the temple of Fortuna now is, a wonderful degree of affection and regret for Cæsar seized the citizens:
tgt_text.4822: in the second place, when the body had been carried into the Forum, and Antonius according to custom had pronounced a funeral oration in honour of Cæsar, see­ ing that the masses were stirred by his speech, he changed their feeling into compassion, and taking the blood- stained vest of Cæsar he unfolded it and showed the rents and the number of the wounds.
tgt_text.4823: Upon this there was no longer any order kept;
tgt_text.4824: but some called out to kill the murderers, and others, as before in the case of Clodius t the demagogue, tearing up the benches and tables from the workshops and bringing them together made a very large pile;
tgt_text.4825: and placing the corpse upon it in the midst of many temples and asyla and holy places burnt it.
tgt_text.4826: When the fire blazed forth, men from various quarters, approaching and plucking out half-burnt pieces of wood, ran about to the houses of Cæsar's assassins, intending to fire them.
tgt_text.4827: But they were already well prepared and repelled the danger.
tgt_text.4828: Now there was one Cinna,t a man given to poetry, who was under no imputation in the matter, and had even been a friend of Cæsar.
tgt_text.4829: He dreamed in a dream that he was invited by Cæsar to supper and he refused;
tgt_text.4830: but Caesar urged and forced him, and at last, laying hold of his hand, led him to a vast and gloomy place, he following the while unwilling and alarmed.
tgt_text.4831: After having this vision, it hap­ pened that he had a fever in the night.
tgt_text.4832: Nevertheless, in the morning, when Cæsar's body was being carried forth he felt ashamed not to be present, and went out to the abble, who were now in a ferocious mood.
tgt_text.4833: Being seen and supposed to be not the Cinna that he was, but the Cinna who had lately reviled Cæsar before the assembly, he was torn in pieces.
tgt_text.4835: It was mainly through fear on account of this unlucky affair, next after the change in Antonius, that Brutus and his partisans left the city.
tgt_text.4836: They stayed in Antium * at first, with the design of returning to Rome when the popular fury should have passed its height and worn itself out.
tgt_text.4837: And this they expected to take place as a matter of course among numbers which were subject to unsteady and rapid movements, and because they had the Senate in their favour, who without taking any notice of those that had torn Cinna to pieces, sought out and seized those who had attacked the houses of the conspirators.
tgt_text.4838: The people, too, already annoyed at Antonius being nearly established in monarchical power, longed for Brutus, and it was expected that he would, in person, superintend the spectacles t which as prefer it was his duty to exhibit.
tgt_text.4839: But when Brutus heard that many of those who had served under Cæsar and received lands and cities from him, were forming designs against him, and were dropping into the city a few at a time, he did not venture to go, and the people saw the spectacles, which, though Brutus was absent, were furnished without any thrift and in a profuse style.
tgt_text.4840: For he had purchased a great number of wild beasts, and he gave orders that none should be sold or left, but that all should be killed;
tgt_text.4841: and he himself went down to Neapolis and engaged most of the actors.
tgt_text.4842: With respect to a certain Canutius who was much in favour on the theatre, he wrote to his friends that they should get him on the stage by persuasion, for it was not fit that any Greek should be forced.
tgt_text.4843: He also wrote to Cicero and urged him by all means to be present at the spectacles.
tgt_text.4845: While affairs were in this state, another change was brought about by the arrival of the young Cæsar.*
tgt_text.4846: He was the son of Cæsar's niece, but by Cæsar's testament he was left his son and heir:
tgt_text.4847: and he was staying at Apollonia when Cæsar was killed, being engaged with philosophical studies and waiting for Cæsar, who had resolved to march forthwith against the Parthians.
tgt_text.4848: As soon as he heard of Cæsar's death he came to Rome, and by assuming Cæsar's name as a mode of beginning to get the popular favour, and by paying among the citizens the money that was left them, he made a strong party against Antonius, and by distribu­ ting money he got together and assembled many of those who had served under Cæsar.
tgt_text.4849: Now when Cicero took the side of Cæsar through hatred of Antonius, Brutus t rebuked him strongly in his letters, saying that Cicero did not dis­ like a master, but feared a master who hated him, and that his policy was to choose a mild servitude, as he showed by writing and saying, “How good Caesar is !"
tgt_text.4850: But our fathers, he said, did not endure even mild masters.
tgt_text.4851: He said that for his part at this crisis he had neither quite resolved to fight nor to remain quiet, but he was resolved on one thing only, not to be a slave;
tgt_text.4852: but he wondered at Cicero, that he was afraid of a civil war and one attended with danger, and was not afraid of a base and inglorious peace, and that he asked as a reward for ejecting Antonius from the tyranny, to be allowed to make Caesar a tyrant.
tgt_text.4854: Now in his first letters Brutus thus expressed himself;
tgt_text.4855: but when people were separating themselves, some on the side of Cæsar and some on the side of Antonius, and the armies being venal were selling them­ selves as it were by auction to the highest bidder, Brutus, altogether despairing of affairs, resolved to leave Italy, and he went by land through Lucania to Velia * to the sea.
tgt_text.4856: From this place Porcia, intending to turn back to Rome, endeavoured to conceal her excessive emotion, but a paint­ ing made her betray herself though she was a noble- spirited woman.

tgt_text.4860: - Hector, thou art to me father and mother dear, And brother too, and husband in thy bloom:

tgt_text.4866: Having set out thence Brutus sailed towards Athens.‡
tgt_text.4867: The people received him gladly with expres­ sions of good wishes and public honours, and he lodged with a friend.
tgt_text.4868: As he attended the discourses of Theomnestus the Academic, and Cratippus * the Peri­ patetic, and associated with those philosophers, it Was supposed that he was altogether inactive and was un­ bending himself.
tgt_text.4869: But he was busied about preparations for war, when no one suspected it;
tgt_text.4870: for he sent Herostratus into Macedonia with the view of gaining over those who were with the armies there, and he attached to himself and kept with him the young men from Rome who were residing at Athens for the sake of their studies.
tgt_text.4871: Among them was also a son of Cicero whom Brutus particularly commends, and says, that whether he is waking or sleep­ ing, he admires him for his noble disposition and hatred of tyrants.
tgt_text.4872: Having now begun openly to attend to affairs, and hearing that Roman vessels full of money were sailing over from Asia, with a commander on board who was an honest man and an acquaintance of his, he met him near Carystus and having fallen in with him and persuaded him and obtained a surrender of the vessels, he prepared for a magnificent entertainment, for it was the birth-day of Brutus.
tgt_text.4873: When they had come to drinking and were pouring out wine with wishes for the success of Brutus and the liberty of the Romans, Brutus, wishing to encourage them still more, asked for a larger cup, and taking it up, without anything moving thereto, he uttered the following verse:
tgt_text.4874: “Me evil fate and Leto's son t have slain."
tgt_text.4875: In addition to this they report that when he went out to fight the last battle at Philippi, Apollo was the word that he gave to his soldiers.
tgt_text.4876: Accordingly they consider that the utterance of that verse was a sign of what was to befall him.
tgt_text.4878: After this Antistius gave Brutus fifty ten thousands out of the money which he was taking to Italy ;
tgt_text.4879: and all the soldiers of Pompeius who were still rambling about Thessaly gladly flocked to Brutus;
tgt_text.4880: and he took five hundred horsemen from Cinna who was conducting them into Asia to Dolabella.*
tgt_text.4881: He then sailed against Demetrias t and got possession of a large quantity of arms, which were going to be carried away to Antonius, and had been made at the command of the elder Cæsar for the Parthian war.
tgt_text.4882: Hortensius,t the governor, also surrendered Macedonia to him, and the kings and rulers all around began to side with him and to come over;

tgt_text.4884: Brutus, intending to anticipate and prevent him, immediately put in motion those who were with him, and marched through a difficult country in the midst of a snow-storm ;
tgt_text.4885: and he was far in advance of those who con­ veyed the provisions.
tgt_text.4886: As he came near Epidamnus, he began to suffer from bulimy || through exhaustion and cold.
tgt_text.4887: This malady chiefly attacks both beasts and men when they are worn out and in the midst of the snow, whether it is that the heat owing to the refrigeration and condens­ ation, when everything is internally compressed, consumes the nourishment all at once, or that a sharp and subtle breath arising from the snow penetrating through, cut, the body and destroys the warmth which is dispersed out­ wards from it.
tgt_text.4888: For it seems that heat causes sweats through meeting with the cold and being quenched about the surface;
tgt_text.4889: whereof there has been further discussion in another place.
tgt_text.4891: As Brutus was fainting, and no one in the army had anything to eat, his attendants were compelled to fly for refuge to their enemies, and approaching the gates they asked bread of the watch, who hearing of the mishap of Brutus came and brought to eat and to drink.
tgt_text.4892: In return for which, when Brutus got possession of the city, he not only treated them kindly, but also all the rest for their sake.
tgt_text.4893: Caius Antonius now came up to Apollonia and summoned the soldiers who were there;
tgt_text.4894: but when they went over to Brutus, and he perceived that the people of Apollonia were in favour of Brutus, he left the city and marched to Buthrotum.*

tgt_text.4897: fur Brutus employed Cicero in command and gained many successes through him.
tgt_text.4898: Brutus himself came upon Caius, who was in marshy ground and far separated from the rest of his troops, but he would not let his lien make an attack, and he threw his cavalry around him with orders to spare the men, saying that in a short time they would be theirs;

tgt_text.4900: Now Brutus treated Caius respectfully for some time and did not deprive him of the insignia of his office, though, as they say, many persons, and Cicero among the rest, wrote to him from Rome and urged him to do it.
tgt_text.4901: But as Caius began to have secret conferences with the officers and attempted to excite a mutiny, he had him put in a ship and guarded.
tgt_text.4902: The soldiers who had been corrupted fled to Apollonia and invited Brutus there, but Brutus said that this was not the custom among the Romans, and that they must come to their general, and ask pardon for their offence.
tgt_text.4903: They came, and Brutus pardoned them at their prayer.
tgt_text.4905: As Brutus was going to set out for Asia, news arrived of the changes at Rome.
tgt_text.4906: The young Caesar had been strengthened by the Senate against Antonius, whom he had driven out of Italy, and he was now formidable, and was seeking for the consulship contrary to law, and maintaining large armies of which the State had no need.
tgt_text.4907: But when Cæsar saw that the Senate was displeased at this, and was looking abroad towards Brutus and decreeing provinces * for him and confirming them, he became alarmed.
tgt_text.4908: And he sent to Antonius and invited him to friendship, and placing his troops around the city he got the consul­ ship, being yet hardly a young man, but in his twentieth year, as he said in his Memoirs.
tgt_text.4909: He immediately instituted a pr< secution on a charge of murder against Brutus and his partisans, for having put to death without trial the first man in the state who was filling the highest offices ;
tgt_text.4910: and he named as the accuser of Brutus, Lucius Cornificius, and Marcus Agrippa as the accuser of Cassius.
tgt_text.4911: Accord­ ingly they were condemned for default of appearance, the judices being compelled to go to the vote.
tgt_text.4912: It is said that when the crier, according to custom, from the tribunal summoned Brutus into court, the mass gave a loud groan, and the nobles bent their heads to the ground and kept silence;
tgt_text.4913: but that Publius Silicius was seen to shed tears, and for this reason was shortly after one of those who were proscribed.
tgt_text.4914: After this, the three, Cæsar, Antonius and Lepidus, distributed the provinces among them, and caused the slaughter and proscription of two hundred men, among whom Cicero perished.
tgt_text.4916: When the news of these events reached Macedonia, Brutus,† compelled by circumstances, wrote to Hortensius to put Caiu8 Antonius to death, on the ground of avenging Brutus and Cicero, the one being his friend, and the other both a friend and kinsman.
tgt_text.4917: This was the reason why Antonius, when he afterwards took Hortensius at Philippi, put him to death on the tomb of his brother.
tgt_text.4918: Brutus says that he felt more shame at the cause of Cicero'is death than sympathy at his misfortune, and that he blamed his friends in Rome, for they were slain more through their own fault than that of the tyrants, and that they submitted to see and to witness what it should have been intolerable for them even to hear.
tgt_text.4919: Brutus having taken his army over to Asia, which was now a considerable force, set about fitting out a naval force in Bithynia* and in the neighbourhood of Cyzicus;
tgt_text.4920: and himself moving about with his troops settled the cities and had interviews with the rulers;
tgt_text.4921: and he sent to Cassius t into Syria to recall him from Egypt;
tgt_text.4922: for he said that it was not to get dominion, but to deliver their country that they were rambling about and collecting a force with which they would put down the tyrants;
tgt_text.4923: that they ought therefore, remembering and keeping in mind this purpose, not to hold themselves far from Italy, but to hasten thither and to aid the citizens.
tgt_text.4924: Cassius obeyed, and Brutus met him on his return;
tgt_text.4925: and they fell in with one another near Smyrna, for the first time since they had separated in Peiraeus and set out, the one for Syria, the other for Macedonia.
tgt_text.4926: They had accordingly great pleasure and confidence owing to the force which each had.
tgt_text.4927: For they had hurried from Italy like the most despicable fugitives, without money and without arms, without a single ship, a single soldier, or a city, and yet after no very long interval they had come together with ships and troops and horses and money, able to struggle for the supremacy of the Romans.
tgt_text.4929: Now Cassius was desirous to have and to allow an equal share of honour, but Brutus herein anticipated him by generally going to Cassius who, in age, was his superior, and in body was not able to sustain equal toil.
tgt_text.4930: The opinion was that Cassius was skilled in military matters, but was violent in passion and governed mainly by fear, while towards his intimates he was too much inclined to use ridicule and was too fond of jesting.
tgt_text.4931: As to Brutus, they say that he was esteemed by the many for his virtues, but loved by his friends, admired by the nobles, and not hated even by his enemies, because the man was extraordinarily mild and high-minded and un­ moved by anger, pleasure or love of aggrandisement, and kept his judgment upright and unbending in tt e main­ tenance of honour and justice.
tgt_text.4932: That which got him most good-will and reputation was the faith which men had in his motives.
tgt_text.4933: For neither that great Pompeius, if he had put down Cæsar, was confidently expected to give up his power to the laws, but to retain affairs in his hands, pacifying the people with the name of consulship and dictatorship or some other title with more pleasing name;
tgt_text.4934: and this Cassius, who was a violent and passionate man and was often carried away from justice in quest of gain, more than any one else they thought would carry on war, and ramble about and expose himself to danger for the purpose of getting power for himself, not liberty for the citizens.
tgt_text.4935: For as to the men of still earlier times, the Cinnas and Marii and Carbos, they viewed their country as a prize and booty for competition, and all but in express words fought to get a tyranny.
tgt_text.4936: But as to Brutus, they say that not even his enemies imputed to him such a change in his purpose, but that many persons had heard Antonius say, he thought Brutus was the only person who conspired against Cæsar because of being moved by the splendour and apparent noble nature of the deed, and that the rest combined against the man because they hated and envied him.
tgt_text.4937: Accordingly it appears from what Brutus says that he trusted not so much in his power as in his virtues.
tgt_text.4938: He wrote to Atticus when he was just approach­ ing the danger, that his affairs were in the best plight as to fortune, for that he should either get the victory and tree the Roman people, or should die and be released from slavery;
tgt_text.4939: and though everything else was safe and secure for them, one thing was uncertain, whether they should live and be free or die.
tgt_text.4940: He says that Marcus Antonius was paying a just penalty for his folly, for while he might have been numbered with the Bruti and Cassii and Catos, he made himself an appendage to Octavius, and if he should not be defeated with him, he would shortly after have to fight against him.
tgt_text.4941: Now he seems, in say­ ing this, to have well divined what was to happen.
tgt_text.4943: While they were then in Smyrna, Brutus claimed a share of the money which Cassius had collected to a great amount, for Brutus alleged that he had expended all his own resources in building so great a fleet with which they would command all the internal sea.*
tgt_text.4944: But the friends of Cassius were not for lettinghim give up the money, saying, “What you save by economy and get with odium, it in not fair that he should take and apply to gaining popular­ ity and gratifying the soldiers."

tgt_text.4947: “I am neither king nor lord, but the executioner and punisher of lord and king."
tgt_text.4948: Brutus demanded of the Lycians money and men.
tgt_text.4949: When Naucrates the demagogue persuaded the cities to revolt, and the people occupied certain heights to prevent Brutus from passing, in the first place he sent cavalry against them when they were eating, who killed six hundred of them;
tgt_text.4950: and in the next place taking posses­ sion of the posts and forts, he released all the people with­ out ransom with the view of gaining over the nation by kindness.
tgt_text.4951: But the people were obstinate, being enraged at what they had suffered, and despising his moderation and humanity, till at last Brutus drove into Xanthus t the most warlike of the Lycians, and blockaded them there.
tgt_text.4952: Some of them attempted to escape by swimming under the river which flowed by the city:
tgt_text.4953: but they were caught by nets which were sunk in the channel to the bottom, and the tops of the nets had bells attached to them which gave a signal as soon as any one was caught.
tgt_text.4954: The Xanthians, making a sally by night, threw fire on certain engines;
tgt_text.4955: and when they were driven back into the town by the Romans who perceived them, and a strong wind began to blow against the battlements the flame which was laying hold of the adjoining houses, Brutus, who feared for the city, ordered his soldiers to help to extinguish the fire.
tgt_text.4957: But the Lycians were all at once seized with a horrible impulse to despair surpassing all description, which might be best likened to a passion for death;
tgt_text.4958: for with their wives and children, both freemen and slaves, and people of every age, they threw missiles from the walls upon the enemy who were assisting to quench the flames, and carrying reeds and wood and everything combustible, they drew the fire to the city, offering to it all kinds of mate­ rial and in every way exciting and feeding it.
tgt_text.4959: As the flames rushed onwards and engirdling the city blazed forth with violence, Brutus, in great affliction at what was going on, rode round the walls, being eager to save the people, and stretching out his hands to the Xanthians he prayed them to spare themselves and save the city;
tgt_text.4960: and yet no one regarded him, but in every way they sought to destroy themselves;
tgt_text.4961: and not only men and women, but even the little children;
tgt_text.4962: with cries and shouts, some leaped into the fire and others broke their necks from the walls, and others presented their throats to their fathers' knives, baring them and bidding them strike.
tgt_text.4963: After the city was destroyed, there was found a woman suspended by a rope, with a dead child hung to her neck, and firing the house with a lighted torch.
tgt_text.4964: This tragical sight Brutus could not endure to see, and he wept at hearing of it;
tgt_text.4965: and he proclaimed that a reward should be given to every soldier who could save a Lycian.
tgt_text.4966: They say that there were only one hundred and fifty who did not escape being saved.
tgt_text.4967: Now the Xanthians after a long interval, as if they were reproducing a fated period of destruction, renewed the fortune of their an­ cestors in their desperation;
tgt_text.4968: for their ancestors in like manner in the time of the Persians burnt their city and destroyed themselves.
tgt_text.4970: Brutus seeing that the city of Patara was pre­ paring to resist him was unwilling to attack it, and was perplexed because he feared the same desperation;
tgt_text.4971: and as he had their women captive, he let them go without ransom.
tgt_text.4972: These women, who were the wives and daughters of distinguished men, reported of Brutus that he was a most moderate and just man, and they persuaded the citizens to yield and to surrender the city.
tgt_text.4973: Upon this all the rest of the Lycians surrendered and gave themselves up to him, and they found him to be honourable and merciful beyond their expectation;
tgt_text.4974: for while Cassius about the same time compelled all the Rhodians to bring in the gold and silver which was their private property, and a sum of eight thousand talents was thus collected, and mulcted the commonwealth of the city in five hundred talents besides, Brutus only demanded of the Lycians a hundred and fifty talents, and without doing them any other wrong set out for Ionia.
tgt_text.4976: Now Brutus did many deeds worthy of remem­ brance both in rewarding and punishing according to desert;
tgt_text.4977: but that with which he himself was most pleased and the best of the Romans, I will relate.
tgt_text.4978: When Pompeius Magnus landed in Egypt at Pelusium, what time he fled after being completely defeated by Cæsar, the guardians of the king, who was still a youth, being in counsel with their friends, were not inclined the same way in their opinions.
tgt_text.4979: Some were for receiving and others for driving the man from Egypt.
tgt_text.4980: But one Theodotus * of Chios, who was hired to teach the king rhetoric, and was then thought worthy of a place in the council for want of better men, attempted to show that both were in error, those who advised to receive and those who advised to send away Pompeius, for there was one thing in the present circum stances that was useful, and that was to receive him and put him to death.
tgt_text.4981: And he added, at the end of his speech, that a corpse does not bite.
tgt_text.4982: The council assented to his opinion, and Pompeius Magnus fell, an instance of things passing belief and expectation, and the result of the rhetorical skill and eloquence of Theodotus, as the sophist himself used to say boastingly.

tgt_text.4984: and Theodotus, who borrowed from fortune a short period for an inglorious and poor and rambling life, did not escape Brutus when he came into Asia, but he was carried before him and punished, and thus he gained a greater name by his death than by his life.

tgt_text.5015: When they were going to cross over from Asia, it is said that Brutus had a great sign.
tgt_text.5016: The man was naturally wakeful, and by discipline and temperance he contracted his sleep into a small space of time, never reposing in the daytime, and by night only so long as he was unable to do anything or to speak to any one because people were resting.
tgt_text.5017: But at that time when the war was on foot, having on his hands the general management of everything, and his thoughts being on the stretch with regard to the future, when he had taken a short repose after eating, he employed the rest of the night on affairs of urgency.
tgt_text.5018: And when he had finished and arranged everything that was necessary about such matters, he would read a book till the third watch, at which time the centurions and tribunes were used to come to him.
tgt_text.5019: Being then about to convey his army over from Asia, it happened to be dead of night and the lamp in his tent was not very bright;
tgt_text.5020: and the whole camp was in deep silence.
tgt_text.5021: As Brutus was considering and reflecting with himself, he thought that he heard some one come in, and looking towards the entrance he saw a terrible and strange vision of a huge and frightful figure standing by him in silence.
tgt_text.5022: He had the courage to ask, " What man or god art thou, or with what purpose dost thou come to us ? "
tgt_text.5023: The phantom replied to him, " I am thy evil daemon, Brutus, and thou shalt see me at Philippic And Brutus without being dis­ turbed, said, " I shall see.
tgt_text.5025: When the phantom disappeared, Brutus called the slaves, and as they said that they had neither heard any voice nor seen anything, Brutus still kept awake;
tgt_text.5026: and at daybreak he betook himself to Cassius and told him his vision.
tgt_text.5027: Cassius, who followed the doctrines of Epicurus, and was accustomed to dispute about them with Brutus, said, “Our opinion, Brutus, is this, that we do not in fact feel all things nor see them, but perception is a certain flexible and deceitful thing, and the intellect is still quicker to move and change it, without there being any real thing, into all forms.
tgt_text.5028: For the fashioning of the form is like unto wax, and as the soul of man possesses both the thing to be fashioned and that which fashions, being the same, it has of itself the power of most easily varying itself and assum­ ing different forms.
tgt_text.5029: And this is shown by the changes of our dreams in sleep, which changes the phantastic power undergoes, from slight causes assuming every kind of effect and image.
tgt_text.5030: It is the nature of the phantastic power to be always in motion, and motion is to it a certain phantasy or perception.
tgt_text.5031: In you the body being troubled naturally excites and perverts the mind.
tgt_text.5032: But it is neither probable that there are daemons, nor that, if there are, they have the form of men or the voice, or that their power reaches to us;
tgt_text.5033: and indeed I wish it were so, that we might not put trust only in arms and horses and so many ships, but also in the help of the gods being the leaders in most upright and noble undertakings."
tgt_text.5034: By such arguments as these Cassius attempted to calm Brutus.
tgt_text.5035: When the soldiers were embarking, two eagles descended on the first standards and were carried along with them, and accompanied the soldiers, who fed them, as far as Philippi.
tgt_text.5036: And there, one day before the battle, they flew away.
tgt_text.5038: Now Brutus had subjected to him most of the nations that lay in his way:
tgt_text.5039: and if any city or ruler had been passed by, they then brought over all in their progress as far as the sea opposite to Thasos.
tgt_text.5040: In those parts Norbanus * and his troops happened to be encamped in the Straits and about Symbolum;
tgt_text.5041: but Brutus and Cassius getting round them compelled them to withdraw and desert the posts.
tgt_text.5042: They also came very near taking his force, Cæsar staying behind on account of illness;
tgt_text.5043: and they would have done it, if Antonius had not come to their aid with such wonderful expedition that Brutus could scarce believe it.
tgt_text.5044: Cæsar arrived ten days later, and pitched his camp opposite to Brutus:
tgt_text.5045: Antonius took his station opposite to Cassius.
tgt_text.5046: The plain which lay between the armies, the Romans called the Campi Philippi ;
tgt_text.5047: and it was on this occasion that the largest Roman armies were matched against one another.
tgt_text.5048: Now in numbers they were not a little inferior to those of Caesar, but in show and splendour of arms the forces of Brutus outshone the enemy.
tgt_text.5049: For most of their armour was of gold, and silver had been unsparingly supplied, though in other respects Brutus accustomed his officers to a simple and severe habit.
tgt_text.5050: But he thought that the wealth which they had in their hands and about their bodies, would give courage to the more ambitious of honour and would make those who were fond of gain still more courageous, as if the weapons which they held were their property.
tgt_text.5052: Now Cæsar made a lustration * within his lines, and distributed among the soldiers a small allowance of grain and five drachmae apiece for the sacrifice;
tgt_text.5053: but Brutus, who considered this either as proof of Cæsar's poverty or his meanness, first of all performed a lustration for the army under the open sky, according to the custom, and then distributed a number of victims for every cohort, and fifty drachmae to each man, by which he had the advantage over the enemy in the good-will and zeal of his troops.
tgt_text.5054: Notwithstanding this a bad omen, as Cassius considered it, happened during the lustration;
tgt_text.5055: for the lictor brought him his crown reversed.
tgt_text.5056: It is said that on a former occasion, also during a certain spectacle and procession, a golden Victory belonging to Cassius, which was being carried, fell down owing to the bearer slipping.
tgt_text.5057: Besides this many birds of prey daily appeared in the camp and swarms of bees were seen collecting about a certain spot within the lines, which the diviners enclosed in order to get rid of the superstitious fear which was gradually withdrawing even Cassius himself from the principles of Epicurus, and had completely cowed the soldiers.
tgt_text.5058: Owing to this, Cassius was not eager that the matter should be decided at present by a battle, and he was of opinion that they should protract the war, being strong in resources, but in amount of arms and men inferior to the enemy.
tgt_text.5059: But Brutus even before this was eager to settle the matter by the speediest hazard, and thus either to recover freedom for his country, or to relieve from their sufferings all the people who were oppressed by cost and military service and requisitions.
tgt_text.5060: And now seeing that his cavalry was successful and victorious in the skirmishes and encounters of posts, his spirit was raised:
tgt_text.5061: and some desertions to the enemy which took place and imputations and suspicions against others caused many of the friends of Cassius in the council to go over to the opinion of Brutus.
tgt_text.5062: One of the friends of Brutus, Atillius, opposed the opinion of Brutus and advised that they should wait for the winter.
tgt_text.5063: On Brutus asking, Wherein he thought that he would be better after a year, he replied, If in nothing else, I shall live longer.
tgt_text.5064: Cassius was vexed at this, and Atillius gave no small offence to the rest.
tgt_text.5065: Accord­ ingly it was resolved to fight on the next day.
tgt_text.5066: XL. Brutus went to rest after having been in high spirits and engaged in philosophical discourse at supper.
tgt_text.5067: As to Cassius, Messala * says that he supped by himself with a few of his intimates, and appeared thoughtful and silent, though he was not naturally so;
tgt_text.5068: and that after supper he pressed the hand of Messala strongly and said, as he was wont when he was in friendly mood, in the Greek language, " I call you to witness, Messala, that I am in the same situation as Pompeius Magnus, being com­ pelled to cast the die for my country's safety in a single battle.
tgt_text.5069: However, let us have a good heart, looking to fortune, which it is not right to distrust, though we may have resolved badly."
tgt_text.5070: Messala says that these were the last words that Cassius spoke to him and thereon embraced him, and that he was invited * by him to supper for the following day, which was his birthday.
tgt_text.5071: At day­ break there was hung out in the lines of Brutus and of Cassius the signal for the contest, a purple vest, and they met between the two camps, and Cassius said:
tgt_text.5072: " Brutus, I hope we may be victorious and live together happily all the rest of our lives;
tgt_text.5073: but as the chief of human events are the most uncertain, and if the battle results contrary to our expectation, it will not be easy for us to see one another, what do you intend with respect to flight or death ?"
tgt_text.5075: When I was a young man, Cassius, and inexperienced in affairs, I know not how it happened that I neglected a weighty matter in philosophy.
tgt_text.5076: I blamed Cato for killing himself, considering that it was not right nor befitting a man to withdraw himself from his daemon, and not to await what happens without fear, but to skulk away.
tgt_text.5077: But now I am of a different mind in the circumstances, and if the deity shall not determine in our favour, I do not want to try other hopes and means, but I will withdraw content with fortune, that on the Ides of March I gave to my country my life and have lived another life for her sake free and glorious."
tgt_text.5078: Whereat Cassius smiled and, embracing Brutus, said, " With such thoughts let us go against the enemy;
tgt_text.5079: for we shall either conquer or we shall not fear the conquerors."
tgt_text.5080: After this they discussed the order of battle in the presence of their friends.
tgt_text.5081: Brutus asked Cassius to allow him to command the right wing, which was supposed to be more appro­ priate for Cassius on account of his experience and his age.
tgt_text.5082: But Cassius granted even this, and he commanded Messala with the bravest of the legions to be posted on the right.
tgt_text.5083: Brutus immediately led forth the cavalry equipped in splendid style, and he brought up the infantry with equal expedition.
tgt_text.5085: The soldiers of Antonius happened to be driving trenches from the marshes, around which they were en­ camped, into the plain and cutting off the approaches of Cassius to the sea.
tgt_text.5086: Caesar was on the watch, not being present himself by reason of sickness, but his troops were there, which, however, did not expect that the enemy would fight, but would merely make sallies against the works and disturb the diggers with light missiles and shouts;
tgt_text.5087: and as they were paying no attention to those who were opposed to them, they were surprised at the shouts about the trenches, which were indistinct and loud.
tgt_text.5088: In the meantime billets came from Brutus to the officers in which the word was written, and as he was advancing on horseback before the legions and encouraging them, a few had time to hear the word as it was passed along, but the greater part without waiting, with one impulse and shout rushed against the enemy.
tgt_text.5089: Some irregularity arose in the lines and some separation of them through this disorder, and the legion of Messala first and those which were close upon it outflanked Cæsar's left;
tgt_text.5090: and having slightly touched the soldiers on the extreme left and killed no great number, but completely outflanking them, fell on the camp.
tgt_text.5091: Caesar, as he says in his Memoirs, inasmuch as one of his friends, Artorius Marcus,* had seen a vision in his sleep which bade Cæsar get out of the way and leave the camp, bad just before been conveyed out of it, and he was supposed to have lost his life ;
tgt_text.5092: for the enemy pierced his empty litter with javelins and spears.
tgt_text.5093: And there was a slaughter in the camp of those who were captured, and two thousand Lacedæmonians, who had lately come as allies, were cut to pieces with them.
tgt_text.5095: They who had not surrounded the soldiers of Caesar, but had engaged with those in front, easily put to flight the enemy who were in confusion, and destroyed at close quarters three legions, and they rushed into the camp with the fugitives, carried along by the impetuosity of success and having Brutus with them;
tgt_text.5096: but what the victors did not see, that the critical time showed to the vanquished.
tgt_text.5097: For pushing forward to the parts of the opposite line which were exposed and broken where the right wing was drawn off in the pursuit, they did not force the centre but were engaged in a violent struggle;
tgt_text.5098: but they put to flight the left, which was in disorder and ignorant of what had happened, and pursuing it to the camp they plundered it, neither of the Imperatores being with them.
tgt_text.5099: For Antonius, as they say, having at the beginning avoided the attack, retreated to the marsh, and Cæsar could no­ where be seen, as he had fled from the camp;
tgt_text.5100: but some showed their bloody swords to Brutus supposing they had killed him, and describing his appearance and age.
tgt_text.5101: And now the centre had repelled their opponents with great slaughter;
tgt_text.5102: and Brutus thought that he was completely victorious as Cassius thought that he was defeated.
tgt_text.5103: And this was the only thing which ruined their cause, that Brutus did not aid Cassius because he thought that he was victorious, and that Cassius did not wait for Brutus be­ cause he thought that he had perished;
tgt_text.5104: for Messala con­ siders it a proof of victory that Brutus had taken three eagles and many standards from the enemy, and the enemy had taken nothing.
tgt_text.5105: Brutus now retreating after he had destroyed Cæsar's camp, was surprised not to see the tent of Cassius standing out conspicuous, as usual, nor the rest in their place, for most of the tents had immediately been thrown down and torn in pieces by the enemy when they broke in.
tgt_text.5106: But those who thought they could see better than their comrades said to Brutus that they saw many helmets glittering and many silver shields moving about in the camp of Cassius, and they said it did not appear to them that it was either the number or the armour of those were left to guard the camp, but yet there did not appear to be in that direction a number of corpses such as might be expected if so many legions had been defeated.
tgt_text.5107: This was the first thing that gave Brutus an idea of the misfortune ;
tgt_text.5108: and leaving a guard in the camp of the enemy he recalled the pursuers and got them together to aid Cassius.
tgt_text.5110: And it had fared thus with him.
tgt_text.5111: He was neither pleased at seeing the first onset of the soldiers of Brutus without signal and order, nor was he pleased that when they were victorious they rushed straight to plunder and profit, taking no pains to get round and encircle the enemy.
tgt_text.5112: Cassius, conducting his operations rather with delay and waste of time than with vigour and judgment, was surrounded by the right wing of the enemy;
tgt_text.5113: and when he saw that, as soon as the cavalry broke away in flight to the sea, the infantry also were giving way, lie endeavoured to stop and recall them.
tgt_text.5114: He also seized the standard from one of the standard-bearers who was flying, and fixed it in the ground before his feet, though even those who were placed about his person no longer remained with any spirit.
tgt_text.5115: In these circumstances, being pressed, ho retreated with a few men to a hill which had a view to­ wards the plain.
tgt_text.5116: He saw nothing in the plain, or with difficulty the plunder of the camp, for he was weak of vision;
tgt_text.5117: but the horsemen around him saw many approach­ ing whom Brutus sent.
tgt_text.5118: Cassius conjectured that they were enemies and were in pursuit of him;
tgt_text.5119: yet he sent Titinius, one of those who were with him, to see.
tgt_text.5120: The horsemen did not fail to observe him approaching, and when they saw a man who was a friend, and faithful to Cassius, they shouted for joy, and some of his friends leap­ ing down from their horses embraced him and took his hand, and the rest riding round him with joyful shouts and clatter by their unmeasured rejoicing produced the greatest misfortune.
tgt_text.5121: For Cassius was quite sure that Titinius was caught by the enemy.
tgt_text.5122: With these words, “Through love of life have I waited to see a friend seized by the enemy," he retired into an empty tent dragging after him one of his freed men, Pindarus, whom, in the un­ fortunate affair of Crassus, he had prepared for this ex­ tremity.
tgt_text.5123: Cassius escaped the Parthians, but now drawing his cloak over his head and baring his neck he presented it to be cut asunder;
tgt_text.5124: for the head was found separated from the body.
tgt_text.5125: But no man saw Pindarus after the death of Cassius, which made some persons think that he had killed Cassius without his order.
tgt_text.5126: Shortly after the horse­ men appeared, and Titinius crowned by them went up to Cassius.
tgt_text.5127: But when, by the weeping and cries of his friends who were lamenting and bewailing, he knew of the fate of the general and of his error, he drew his sword and with much upbraiding of himself for his tardiness killed him­ self.
tgt_text.5129: Brutus, who was acquainted with the defeat of Cassius, was now approaching, and he heard of his death when he was near the camp.
tgt_text.5130: After lamenting over the body and calling Cassius the last of the Romans, as if he considered that such a spirit could never again be produced in Rome, he wrapped up the corpse and sent it to Thasos, that no disorder might be produced by its being interred there.
tgt_text.5131: He summoned the soldiers together and consoled them ;
tgt_text.5132: and seeing that they were deprived of all necessaries he promised them two thousand drachmae apiece in place of what they had lost.
tgt_text.5133: The soldiers were encouraged by his words and admired the magnitude of his present;
tgt_text.5134: and they accompanied him with shouts as he went away, mag­ nifying him as the only one of the four Imperatores who was un vanquished in battle.
tgt_text.5135: And the result proved that he had good reason for trusting to success in the battle;
tgt_text.5136: for with a few legions he put to flight all those who opposed him.
tgt_text.5137: But if he had employed all his forces in the battle, and the greater part had not passed by the enemy and fallen on the enemy's baggage, it is probable that he would have left no part of the enemy's force un­ vanquished.
tgt_text.5139: There fell on the side of Brutus eight thousand, with the slaves who were with them in the army, whom Brutus called Briges;
tgt_text.5140: * and of the enemy Messala says that he thinks more than twice the number fell.
tgt_text.5141: For this reason the enemy was the more dispirited, till a slave of Cassius, named Demetrius, came to Antonius as soon as it was evening, having taken the cloaks from the corpse, and the sword;
tgt_text.5142: and when these were brought, they were so much encouraged that at daybreak they led forth their force prepared for battle.
tgt_text.5143: But as both his armies were in an unsettled and dangerous state (for his own army being full of captives required careful watching, and the army of Cassius was troubled at the loss of their general, and they felt somewhat of envy and dislike in consequence of their defeat towards the army that had been victorious), Brutus resolved to put his troops under arms, but he would not fight.
tgt_text.5144: Of the captives, he ordered the slaves to be killed, as they were moving about among the soldiers in a suspicious way;
tgt_text.5145: but of the freemen he released some, saying that they had rather been made captives by the enemy, and were captives and slaves there, but with him were free men and citizens;
tgt_text.5146: and when he saw that his friends and the officers were ill-disposed towards them, he saved them by concealing them and sending them away.
tgt_text.5147: There were a certain Volumnius,* a mime, and Saculio, a jester, among the prisoners, whom Brutus cared not for, and his friends bringing these to him accused them of not abstaining even now from speaking and jeering to insult them.
tgt_text.5148: Brutus was silent, being occupied with other thoughts, but Messala Corvinus was of opinion that they should be flogged in a tent, and given up naked to the generals of the enemy, that they might know what kind of drinking companions and intimates they wanted in their campaigns.
tgt_text.5149: Some of those who were present laughed;
tgt_text.5150: but Publius Casca, who had struck Cæsar first, said, " We offer no fit sacrifice to Cassius who is dead, by making merry and jesting;
tgt_text.5151: but you, Brutus,” he said, " will show what remembrance you have of the general either by punishing or protecting those who will mock and revile him."
tgt_text.5152: Upon this Brutus, greatly angered, said, " Why then do you ask me, Casca, and why don't you do what you like ? "
tgt_text.5153: This answer of Brutus they considered as an assent to the punishment of the unhappy men, whom they led away and put to death.
tgt_text.5155: After this Brutus gave the soldiers their present, and blaming them mildly for not having waited for the word, and having fallen on the enemy somewhat disorderly without waiting for the order, he promised them if they were victorious to give up to them for plunder and profit two cities, Thessalonica * and Lacedaemon.
tgt_text.5156: This is the only thing in the life of Brutus which he is charged with that admits of no defence, though Antonius and Caesar paid to their soldiers a much more terrible price as the reward of their victories, for they drove the old settlers out of nearly the whole of Italy, that their soldiers might have land and cities to which they had no claim.
tgt_text.5157: But with Antonius and Cæsar dominion and power was the end which they proposed to themselves in the war, while Brutus, owing to his reputation for virtue, was not allowed by the many either to conquer or to save his life otherwise than by honourable and just means;
tgt_text.5158: and especially now that Cassius was dead, who had the imputation of urging Brutus on to some of his more violent acts.
tgt_text.5159: But as at sea when the helm is broken, they attempt to nail on other pieces of wood, and to fit them, not skilfully indeed, but as well as they can under circumstances, fighting against the necessity, so Brutus with so great a force around him, and in so hazardous a state of affairs, having no commander of equal weight with himself, was compelled to employ those who were with him, and to do and say many things accord ing to their pleasure.
tgt_text.5160: And he judged it fit to do whatever he thought would improve the disposition of the soldiers of Cassius, for they were difficult to manage :
tgt_text.5161: in the camp being unruly for want of discipline, and towards the enemy having a feeling of cowardice by reason of their defeat.
tgt_text.5163: Affairs were no better with Caesar and Antonius, for they were scantily supplied with provisions, and owing to the camp being pitched in a hollow, they expected a bad winter.
tgt_text.5164: For being among marshes and the autumnal rains coming on after the battle, they had their tents filled with mud and with water which froze immediately through the cold.
tgt_text.5165: While they were in this condition, news arrived of the misfortune that had befallen their forces at sea.
tgt_text.5166: For the ships of Brutus * fell upon them, and destroyed a large force that was coming to Cæsar from Italy, and only a very few of the men escaped, who were compelled by famine to eat the sails and ropes.
tgt_text.5167: On hearing this news they were eager to settle the matter by a battle before Brutus was aware of the great good fortune that had come to him;
tgt_text.5168: for it happened that in the same day the battle by land and the battle by sea were determined.
tgt_text.5169: But by some chance rather than through the fault of the commanders of the fleet, Brutus was ignorant of the success, though twenty days had elapsed.
tgt_text.5170: For otherwise he would not have gone out to a second battle when he was provided with all necessaries for his army for a long time and was posted in a good position, wherein he could have maintained his army in the winter free from all suffering and safe against the attacks of the enemy, and by being master of the sea, and having defeated by land the troops opposed to him, was in high hopes and spirits.
tgt_text.5171: But affairs, as it appears, being no longer governable by a number, and requiring a monarchy, the deity wishing to lead away and to remove the only person who stood in the way of him who was able to govern, cut off the news of that good fortune, though it came exceeding near to being communicated to Brutus.
tgt_text.5172: For the day before that on which he was going to fight, and late in the day, there came one Clodius, a deserter from the enemy, who reported, that Cæsar was eager to come to a decisive contest because he had heard of the destruction of his armament.
tgt_text.5173: The man got no credit for his report nor did he come into the presence of Brutus, being altogether despised as one who had heard no well-founded news, or reported falsehood to get favour.
tgt_text.5175: In that night it is said that the phantom again appeared to Brutus, and displaying the same appear­ ance said nothing and went away.
tgt_text.5176: But Publius Volum­ nius,* a philosopher and one who accompanied Brutus in his campaign from the first, says that this was not the sign;
tgt_text.5177: but he says that the first eagle was covered with bees, and from the arm of one of the centurions an oil of roses spontaneously burst out, and though they often rubbed it off and wiped it away, it was all to no use.
tgt_text.5178: Further, before the battle, two eagles met and fought in the space between the armies, and a silence past belief filled the plain while all were looking on, but at last the eagle which was on the side of Brutus gave way and fled.
tgt_text.5179: The Ethiopian became notorious, he who met the eagle-bearer as soon as the gate was opened, and was cut down with their swords by the soldiers, who considered it a bad omen.
tgt_text.5181: After Brutus had made the line advance, and had placed it in front of the enemy, he paused some time, for suspicions reached him and information against certain persons while he was inspecting the army;
tgt_text.5182: and he observed that the cavalry were not very eager to begin the battle, but were still waiting for the infantry to commence the attack.
tgt_text.5183: All of a sudden, a man of military skill, who had been particularly distinguished for his courage, rode past Brutus himself and passed over to the enemy :
tgt_text.5185: Brutus was greatly pained at seeing this, and partly through passion, partly through fear of greater change and treachery, he forthwith led his men against the enemy, the sun now going down to the ninth hour.
tgt_text.5186: Brutus had the advantage with his own troops, and he pushed on, pressing upon the left wing of the enemy which gave way, and the cavalry supported him by charging together with the infantry the disordered ranks;
tgt_text.5187: but the other wing, which the commanders extended for fear of being surrounded, was inferior in numbers, and was drawn out in the centre, and thus becoming weak, did not resist the enemy, but fled first.
tgt_text.5188: The enemy, having broken this wing, immediately surrounded Brutus, who displayed all the virtues of a general and a soldier, both in his personal exertions, and his prudent measures in the midst of danger to secure victory;
tgt_text.5189: but he was damaged by that circumstance whereby he gained advantage in the former battle.
tgt_text.5190: For in that battle the part of the enemy which was defeated had perished;
tgt_text.5191: but few perished of the troops of Cassius, though they were put to flight, and those who escaped being very timid through their former defeat, filled the chief part of the army with despondency and confusion.
tgt_text.5192: On this occasion also, Marcus the son of Cato,* fighting among the noblest and bravest of the youth, though hard pressed, did not yield nor flee, but laying about him and calling out who he was, and his father's name, he fell on a heap of the enemy's slain.
tgt_text.5193: There fell, too, the bravest of the men, exposing themselves in defence of Brutus.L.
tgt_text.5194: Among the intimates of Brutus was one Lucilius,t a good man.
tgt_text.5195: Observing that some barbarian horsemen in their pursuit paid no regal d to the rest, but rode at full speed after Brutus, he resolved at his own risk to stop them.
tgt_text.5196: And being a little in the rear he said that he was Brutus, and he gained belief by praying them to take him to Antonius, because he feared Cæsar, but trusted in Antonius.
tgt_text.5197: The barbarians delighted at their success, and considering that they had surprising good luck, conducted the man, and as it was now growing dark, sent forward some of their number as messengers to Antonius.
tgt_text.5198: Antonius, much pleased, went to meet those who were conducting Lucilius;
tgt_text.5199: and those who heard that Brutus was being brought alive flocked together, some pitying him for his ill fortune, and others thinking it unworthy of his fame to let himself be taken by barbarians through love of life.
tgt_text.5200: When they were near, Antonius stopped, being doubtful how he should receive Brutus, but Lucilius, approaching with a cheerful countenance, said, " Antonius, no enemy has taken Marcus Brutus, nor will:
tgt_text.5201: may fortune never have such a victory over virtue.
tgt_text.5202: But he will be found, whether alive or dead, in a condition worthy of himself.
tgt_text.5203: But I who have deceived your soldiers am come to suffer, and I deprecate no punishment, however severe, for what I have done."
tgt_text.5204: When Lucilius had said this, and all were in amaze, Antonius, looking on those who conducted Lucilius, said, “ I suppose, fellow soldiers, you are vexed at your mistake, and think that you have been grossly tricked.
tgt_text.5205: But be assured that you have taken a better prey than that which you were in search of.
tgt_text.5206: For while you were seeking for an enemy, you have brought us a friend ;
tgt_text.5207: for as to Brutus, I know not by the gods, what I should have done with him if he were alive, but such men as this, I pray that I may have as friends rather than as enemies."
tgt_text.5208: Saying this he embraced Lucilius and for the time placed him with one of his friends, but he afterwards employed him, and found him in everything faithful and true.
tgt_text.5210: Brutus, having crossed a certain stream, the banks of which were lined with wood and steep, just when it began to be dark, did not advance far, but seating himself in a hollow spot where there was a large rock spread out, with a few of his officers and friends about him, first looked up to the heavens which were full of stars, and uttered two verses, one of which Volumnius has recorded:
tgt_text.5211: “ Forget not,* Jove, the author of these ills;
tgt_text.5212: ” but the other he says that he forgot.
tgt_text.5213: After a while naming each of his companions who had fallen -in battle before his eyes, he grieved most over the memory of Flavius and Labeo.
tgt_text.5214: Labeo was his lieutenant, and Flavius the chief of the engineers.
tgt_text.5215: In the meantime one who was thirsty himself and saw that Brutus was in the same plight, took a helmet and ran down to the river.
tgt_text.5216: As a noise from the opposite side reached their ears, Volumnius went forward to see, and Dardanus the shield- bearer with him.
tgt_text.5217: Returning after a while they asked about the water;
tgt_text.5218: and Brutus, smiling with a very friendly ex­ pression on Volumnius, said, “ It is drunk up, but some more shall be brought for you."
tgt_text.5219: The same person was sent, but he was in danger of being taken by the enemy and escaped with difficulty after being wounded.
tgt_text.5220: As Brutus conjectured that no great number of his men had fallen, Statyllius* undertook to make his way secretly through the enemy, for it was not possible in any other way, and to inspect the camp, and after raising a fire- signal, if he should find all safe there, to come back to him.
tgt_text.5221: The fire-signal was raised, for Statyllius got to the camp, but as a long time elapsed and he did not return, Brutus said, “ If Statyllius is alive he will come."
tgt_text.5222: But it happened that, as he was returning, he fell among the enemy and was killed.
tgt_text.5224: In the course of the night, Brutus, as he sat on the ground, turned to his slave Kleitus and spoke to him But as Kleitus kept silence and shed tears, Brutus drew to him his shield-bearer Dardanus, and privately said some­ thing to him.
tgt_text.5225: At last employing the Greek language he addressed Volumnius and reminded them of their philo­ sophical studies and discipline, and he urged him to put his hand to his sword and to aid him in the thrust.
tgt_text.5226: Volumnius refusing, and the rest being in the same dispose tion, and some one saying that they must not stay there, out fly, Brutus sprang up and said, " Certainly we must fly, yet not with the feet, but with the hands."
tgt_text.5227: Offering his right hand to each with a cheerful countenance, he said that he felt great pleasure, that no one of his friends had deceived him, but he blamed fortune with respect to his country;
tgt_text.5228: as for himself, he considered that he was happier than the conquerors, in that not yesterday nor yet recently, but even now he left behind him a reputa­ tion for virtue, which those would not leave behind who gained the victory by arms or by money, nor would they make people think that unjust and vile men who had de­ stroyed just and upright men did not rule unmeritedly.
tgt_text.5229: After entreating and urging them to save themselves, he retired a little farther with two or three, among whom was Strato who had become intimate with him from being his instructor in rhetoric.
tgt_text.5230: Putting Stiato close to him, and pressing the bare sword with both hands on the handle, he fell upon it and died.
tgt_text.5231: Others say that it was not Brutus himself, but Strato who, at the earnest request of Brutus, held the sword under him, averting his eyes, and that Brutus throwing his breast upon it with violence, and piercing it through, quickly died.
tgt_text.5233: Messala* who was a friend of Brutus and became reconciled to Cæsar, once on a time when Cæsar was at leisure, brought this Strato to him, and with tears in his eyes said, “ This, Cæsar, is the man who did the last service to my Brutus."
tgt_text.5234: Caesar received Strato and kept him about him, and Strato was one of the Greeks who showed themselves brave men in difficulties, and in the battle at Actium.
tgt_text.5235: They say that Messala himself being afterwards commended by Cæsar because, though he had been one of their greatest enemies at Philippi for the sake of Brutus, he had shown himself most zealous at Actium, replied, " Yes, Caesar, I have always been on the better and juster side."
tgt_text.5236: When Antonius found the body of Brutus,* he ordered it to be wrapped in the most costly of his purple vests;
tgt_text.5237: and when he afterwards discovered that the purple vest was stolen, he put the thief to death.
tgt_text.5238: The ashes he sent to Servilia, the mother of Brutus.
tgt_text.5239: Nikolaus t the philosopher and Valerius Maximus ‡ relate that Porcia the wife of Brutus being desirous to die, which none of her friends would allow, but kept close and watched her, snatched burning embers from the fire, and closing her mouth, so died.
tgt_text.5240: Yet there is extant a letter of Brutus § to his friends in which he upbraids them and laments about Porcia, that she was neglected by them and had deter­ mined to die because of her sufferings from disease.
tgt_text.5241: Nikolaus therefore appears not to have known the time, since the letter, if it is genuine, informs us of the malady, and the love of the woman and the manner of her death.
tgt_text.5243: Among the glories of these two men's lives, it is especially to be noticed, that each of them started from small beginnings, and yet raised himself to the highest position in the state;
tgt_text.5244: and this fact is peculiarly honourable to Dion.
tgt_text.5245: Brutus owed much of his success to the help of Caseins, who, though less trustworthy than Brutus in matters of virtue and honour, gave equal proofs of courage, skill, and energy in war, while some writers go so far as to give him the entire credit of the plot against Cæsar, and say that Brutus had no share in it.
tgt_text.5246: Dion on the other hand was obliged to provide himself with friends and fellow conspirators, no less than with arms, ships, and soldiers.
tgt_text.5247: Furthermore, Dion did not, like Brutus, gain wealth and power by the revolution and war which he began, but even gave his own money to support the war, and spent the property on which he might have lived comfortably in exile in order to make his countrymen free.
tgt_text.5248: We must remember, also, that Brutus and Cassius could not have remained quiet after they left Rome, for they had been condemned to death, and were being pursued, so that they were forced to fight in their own defence.
tgt_text.5249: When they risked their lives in battle it was for themselves that they did so more than for their countrymen, whereas Dion lived in exile more happily than the despot who banished him, and nevertheless exposed himself to so terrible a hazard in order to set Sicily free.
tgt_text.5251: Yet it was not the same thing to free the Syracusana from Dionysius and to rid the Romans of Cæsar.
tgt_text.5252: Dionysius never denied that he was a despot, and had inflicted countless miseries upon Sicily:
tgt_text.5253: while the government of Cæsar, though its creation gave great offence, yet when it had been accepted and had overcome all opposition seemed to be a despotism merely in name, for Cæsar did nothing cruel or arbitrary, and rather appeared to have been sent by heaven like a physician, to establish an absolute mon­ archy in as mild a form as possible, at a time when that remedy was necessary for Rome.
tgt_text.5254: In consequence of this the people of Rome were grieved at the death of Cæsar, and showed themselves harsh and inexorable to his mur­ derers;
tgt_text.5255: while the severest charges which were brought against Dion by his countrymen were that he had allowed Dionysius to escape from Syracuse, and that he had not destroyed the tomb of the former despot.
tgt_text.5257: In actual warfare Dion proved himself a faultless general, as he succeeded brilliantly in every enterprise planned by himself, and was able to remedy the failures caused by the misconduct of others ;
tgt_text.5258: while Brutus seems not to have been wise in engaging in the last decisive battle, and when it was lost did not attempt to retrieve his fortunes, but gave himself up to despair, showing even less confidence than Pompeius.
tgt_text.5259: Yet, his position was far from hopeless, for he still retained a large part of his army, and a fleet which gave him entire command of the sea.
tgt_text.5261: Dion cannot be accused of any crime like that which is the greatest blot upon the character of Brutus, who after his life had been saved by Cæsar's goodness, and he had been allowed to save as many as he pleased of his fellow captives, after also he had been regarded by Cæsar as his friend, and had been promoted by Cæsar above many others, murdered his benefactor.
tgt_text.5262: On the contrary, Dion was the relative and friend of Dionysius, and assisted him in maintaining his government, and it was not until he was expelled from his country, his wife wronged, and his property confiscated, that he openly began a most just and lawful war against the despot.
tgt_text.5263: Is there not, however, another view of this question?
tgt_text.5264: That hatred of despotism and wrong which is so highly honoured, was possessed by Brutus pure and unalloyed by personal motives, for he had no private grudge against Cæsar, and yet risked his life on behalf of the liberty of the people :
tgt_text.5265: while Dion would never have made war against Dionysius, if he had not been wronged by him.
tgt_text.5266: This we learn distinctly from PJato's letters, which prove that Dion did not begin his revolt until he was banished by Dionysius, after which he deposed the tyrant.
tgt_text.5267: A common object made Brutus become the friend of Pompeius, who was Cæsar's enemy both personally and politically, for Brutus made men his friends or his enemies solely according to what he thought right:
tgt_text.5268: while Dion assisted Dionysius much while he was on friendly terms with him, and only made war against him out of anger at his loyalty being suspected.
tgt_text.5269: For this reason many even of his own friends believed that after removing Dionysius from the throne he intended to succeed him, and to reign though under some title more plausible than that of despot;
tgt_text.5270: while even the enemies of Brutus admitted that he alone of all the conspirators against Cæsar kept one object con­ sistently in view, which was to restore to the Romans their ancient constitution.
tgt_text.5272: Apart from these considerations the struggle against Dionysius was different from that against Cæsar.
tgt_text.5273: Diony­ sius was despised even by his own associates for wasting all his time with drink, dice, and women ;
tgt_text.5274: whereas it shows a certain magnanimity, and a spirit undismayed by any danger, to have conceived the idea of dethroning Caesar, and not to have been overawed by the wisdom, power, and good fortune of a man whose very name made the kings of Parthia and India uneasy in their sleep.
tgt_text.5275: As soon as Dion appeared in bicily, thousands joined him to attack Diony­ sins, while the power of Cæsar's name even after his death rallied his friends, and enabled a helpless child to become at once the first of the Romans by assuming it, as though it were a talisman to protect him against the might and hatred of Antonius.
tgt_text.5276: If it be said that Dion only drove out Diony­ sius after many fierce battles, whereas Brutus stabbed Cæsar when he was naked and unguarded, yet it was in itself a brilliant piece of generalship to have attacked so powerful a man when he was naked and unguarded:
tgt_text.5277: for he did not attack him on a sudden impulse, or alone, or even with a few associates;
tgt_text.5278: but the plot had been laid long before, and many were concerned in it, yet none be­ trayed him.
tgt_text.5279: Either lie chose only the bravest men, or else the mere fact of their having been chosen and trusted by Brutus made them brave.
tgt_text.5280: Dion on the other hand trusted worthless men;
tgt_text.5281: and this is discreditable to his judgment, for they must either have been villains when he chose them for his followers, or else they must have been originally good, and have become worse during their connection with him.
tgt_text.5282: Plato indeed blames him for choosing such men for his friends, and at last he was murdered by them.
tgt_text.5284: No one avenged the murder of Dion;
tgt_text.5285: but Antonius, though Brutus's enemy, nevertheless buried him with honour, and Caesar (Augustus) allowed the honours which were paid to his memory to remain untouched.
tgt_text.5286: A brazen statue of Brutus stands in the city of Milan, in Gaul, on this side of the Alps.
