tgt_text.6691: The soldiers were so furiously exasperated by these reproaches that they eagerly besought Spurinna to employ them in whatever service he pleased, assuring him that they would not shrink from any toils or dangers.
tgt_text.6692: When the enemy furiously assaulted the walls, and brought up many battering engines,.
tgt_text.6693: Spurinna's men won the victory, drove back their oppo­ nents with great slaughter, and saved from ruin one of the most famous and prosperous cities of Italy.
tgt_text.6694: The generals of Otho were found both by cities and by individuals to be much less offensive to deal with than those of Vitellius.
tgt_text.6695: Among the latter was Cæcina, a man who neither spoke nor dressed like a citizen of Rome, but was harsh and overbearing, of great stature, wearing the Gaulish trousers and sleeves, and using signs t even when addressing Roman magistrates.
tgt_text.6696: He was accompanied by his wife ‡ who rode with him in a showy dress, escorted by a picked body of cavalry.
tgt_text.6697: The other general, Fabius Valens,§ was so avaricious that neither the plunder which he took from the enemy, nor yet the thefts which he committed or the bribes which he received from the allied states could satiate him ;
tgt_text.6698: and he was even suspected of having been too late for the first battle of the war because he delayed his march to amass wealth for himself.
tgt_text.6699: Others blame Cæcina, because in his haste to win a victory before Valens came up, he, besides other blunders of less consequence, began a battle so unseasonably and conducted it so remissly that he very nearly brought the cause of Vitellius to ruin.
tgt_text.6701: After Ceecina's repulse at Placentia he proceeded to Cremona, another large and flourishing city.
tgt_text.6702: Mean­ while Annius Gallus, who was on his way to Placentia to reinforce Spurinna, hearing while on the march that the troops at Placentia had been victorious, but that Cremona was in danger, changed the direction of his march towards that place, and encamped close to the enemy.
tgt_text.6703: Here Cæcina concealed many foot-soldiers in rough and wooded ground ordering his cavalry to ride forward and, if they fell in with the enemy, to retire little by little so as to draw them into the ambuscade.
tgt_text.6704: This plan was betrayed to Celsus by deserters.
tgt_text.6705: Celsus attacked them with the best of his cavalry, pursued them with caution, taking care to avoid the ambuscade, and then surrounded the troops in ambush, and threw them into confusion.
tgt_text.6706: He now sent for his infantry from the camp:
tgt_text.6707: and it was thought that if they had come up promptly after the cavalry, the whole army of Cæcina might have been destroyed;
tgt_text.6708: but as it was, Paullinus brought them up slowly and too late, and tarnished his glory as a general by overcaution.
tgt_text.6709: The mass of the soldiers charged him with treason, and tried to exasperate Otho against him by boasting that they had won the victory, but that their success was not followed up owing to the cowardice of their generals.
tgt_text.6710: Otho, though he did not believe their accusations, yet feared to be thought to disbelieve them.
tgt_text.6711: He accordingly sent his brother Titianus to the army, and with him Julius Proculus, the prefect of the prætorians, who virtually had the supreme command, though Titianus was the nominal chief, while Celsus and Paullinus were given the titles of counsellors and friends, but were not allowed the least real power or authority.
tgt_text.6712: The enemy also showed want of discipline, especially in the army of Valens.
tgt_text.6713: These men, when they heard of the ambuscade and the defeat to which it had led, were greatly enraged at not having been there in time to prevent so great a slaughter of their friends.
tgt_text.6714: Valens * was forced to beg for his life;
tgt_text.6715: for the soldiers were preparing to stone him.
tgt_text.6716: He pacified them with difficulty, and led them to join the forces of Cæcina.
tgt_text.6718: When Otho arrived at the camp at Bedriacum, t which is a village near Cremona, he held a council of war.
tgt_text.6719: Proculus and Titianus were of opinon that, as the troops were full of confidence and flushed with victory, it would be best to fight a decisive battle at once, and not blunt their spirit by delay, which would also bring Vitellius down upon them from Gaul.
tgt_text.6720: On the other hand Paullinus argued that the enemy had already collected their entire available force, whereas Otho might expect another army as large as his present one to join him from Mcesia and Pannonia, if he would only wait until it suited him to fight, and not play into the hands of the enemy by engaging prematurely.
tgt_text.6721: The troops, he said, after being so largely reinforced, would be no less confident than at present, when they are but few ;
tgt_text.6722: indeed, they would fight with a great superiority of numbers.
tgt_text.6723: Besides this, delay would be all in their favour, as they had abundance of supplies, while the opponents, who were in an enemy's country, would soon be reduced to great straits by the want of pro­ visions.
tgt_text.6724: Marius Celsus agreed with the views of Paullinus.
tgt_text.6725: Annius Callus was not present at the council, having been disabled by a fall from his horse:
tgt_text.6726: but when Otho wrote a letter to him, asking his opinion, he advised the emperor not to be hasty, but to await the arrival of the legions which were already on their way from Moesia.
tgt_text.6727: However Otho was not convinced by these arguments, but agreed with those who urged him to fight at once.
tgt_text.6729: Many other reasons for this decision are given by various writers, and it is evident that the prætorians, or bodyguard of the emperor, who now for the first time had experience of actual warfare, were eager to return to their old haunts at Rome, and the unwarlike pleasures of the theatre and the circus, and that their eagerness for battle could not be restrained, as they imagined that they would overthrow their antagonists at the first onset.
tgt_text.6730: It seems, too, that Otho himself could no longer endure the un­ certainty of his position, for his ignorance of war and his life of enervating luxury had unfitted him for a calm calculation of his chances of success, and, worn out as he was with anxiety, he longed to let the matter be settled whichever way chance might determine, like a man who covers his face through dizziness at looking over a precipice.
tgt_text.6731: This is the account which is given by the orator Secundus, who acted as private secretary to Otho.
tgt_text.6732: Other * authorities relate that many efforts were made by the soldiers of both armies to combine, and agree to elect an emperor from among their own officers:
tgt_text.6733: or, if this proved impossible, to place the election in the hands of the senate.
tgt_text.6734: It seems indeed rightly probable, considering the ill-repute of both claimants of the throne, that the more sedate and thought­ ful of the soldiers should have reflected that it would be a horrible and shameful thing that the Romans should be made to suffer for a second time all the miseries which they had once endured in the civil wars of Bulla and of Marius and of Caesar and Pompeius, merely in order to pro­ vide an empire to bear the charges of the gluttony and drunkenness of Vitellius, or of the luxury and profligacy of Otho.
tgt_text.6735: It is suspected that Marius Celsus, knowing that this feeling was gaining ground, endeavoured to gain time, hoping that the whole matter might be decided with­ out fighting;
tgt_text.6736: and that Otho, fearing this, hurried on an engagement.
tgt_text.6738: After the council Otho again retired to Brixellum.
tgt_text.6739: This was a mistake, not only because the army would have fought with greater zeal and discipline when under the eye of the emperor, but because by taking away the best and most loyal troops, both of cavalry and infantry, to act as his bodyguard, he made his army like a spear which has lost its steel point.
tgt_text.6740: At this time a battle took place on the bank of the Padua, across which Cæcina en­ deavoured to throw a bridge, while the Othonians tried to prevent him from doing so.
tgt_text.6741: As they did not succeed" in this, they threw lighted sulphur and pitch into the boats which formed the bridge, and a wind suddenly springing up carried the fire across the stream towards the enemy.
tgt_text.6742: At first volumes of smoke, and then a mass of flames burst out, so that the enemy were thrown into confusion and forced to leap from the bridge into the river, upsetting the boats and exposing themselves to the missiles and the ridicule of the enemy.
tgt_text.6743: However, the Germans were victorious in a fight with Otho's corps of gladiators for the possession of an island in the river, and slew many of them.
tgt_text.6745: As, after this, the soldiers in Otho's camp at Bed­ riacum were frantically eager for battle, Proculus led them forward about six miles from that place and en­ camped in such an ignorant and ridiculous fashion that the men suffered from want of water, although it was spring time, and all the surrounding country was full of springs and perennial streams.
tgt_text.6746: On the next day he wished to lead them at least twelve miles nearer the enemy, but Suetonius Paullinus would not allow him to do so, think­ ing that the soldiers ought to have some rest, and not first be fatigued with a long march, and then while they were confusedly mixed up with baggage animals and campfollowers, be brought to fight against an enemy who could quietly and deliberately place themselves in order of battle.
tgt_text.6747: While the generals were at variance, one of the horsemen called Numidians rode up bearing a letter from Otho, in which he ordered them not to waste any time, but to march against the enemy at once.
tgt_text.6749: Cæcina, hearing of their march, was much disquieted, abandoned his operations by the river, and proceeded to the camp.
tgt_text.6750: Here after Valens had got the men under arms, and had given them the watchword, he sent forward the best of the cavalry while the legions were taking up their respective posi­ tions in the line of battle.
tgt_text.6752: For some reason or other the men of Otho's vanguard conceived an idea that the generals of Vitellius intended to desert to their side :
tgt_text.6753: and so, when they came near to one another, they saluted the Vitellians and ad­ dressed them as friends and comrades.
tgt_text.6754: As the Vitellians made an angry and fierce response, the Othonians were discouraged, while their opponents imagined that they in­ tended to desert.
tgt_text.6755: This incident at the first onset caused some confusion among the troops of Otho:
tgt_text.6756: and, besides this, everything was in disorder, for the baggage train was entangled among the ranks, and the line was broken in many places by the ditches and trenches with which the ground was intersected, so that the soldiers, in trying to avoid these obstacles, were forced to attack in detail, and in disorganised crowds.
tgt_text.6758: legions alone, that named “ Rapax " on the side of Vitellius, and “ Adjutrix" on that of Otho, were able to find a level plain, upon which they deployed into a regular line of battle and fought front to front for a long time.
tgt_text.6759: Otho's soldiers were active and brave, but had never been in action before, while those of Vitellius had fought many battles, but were somewhat elderly and past their prime.
tgt_text.6760: At the first charge the Othonians drove them back, and captured their eagle, killing almost every man in the front rank ;
tgt_text.6761: but the Vitellians, filled with shame and rage, charged in their turn, slew Orfidius, the legate in command of the legion, and took many standards.
tgt_text.6762: The corps of gladiators, who were supposed to possess both courage and practice in close combat, were attacked by Alphenus Varus with the Batavians, who inhabit an island formed by the river Rhine, and who are the best horsemen in Germany.
tgt_text.6763: Few of the gladiators stood to receive their charge, but most of them fled towards the river, where they fell in with other bodies of the enemy, by whom they were en­ tirely cut to pieces.
tgt_text.6764: The worst fight of all was made by the Prætorians, who did not even wait until the enemy reached them, but by their panic flight struck terror even into the unbroken troops through whose ranks they fled.
tgt_text.6765: Yet many of Otho's troops, after having conquered their immediate opponents, forced their way back through their victorious enemies to their own camp.
tgt_text.6767: Of the generals, neither Proculus nor Paullinus dared to return with their men, but went off another way, fearing the soldiers, who already began to throw the blame of their defeat upon the generals.
tgt_text.6768: Annius Gallus assumed the command of the soldiers as they assembled in the town of Bedriacum, and encouraged them by assurances that the battle had been a drawn one, and that in many cases they had beaten the enemy.
tgt_text.6769: Marius Celsus called a meet­ ing of the generals, and bade them take measures for the common good.
tgt_text.6770: He said that after so great a disaster and so much slaughter of their countrymen not even Otho him­ self, if he were a right-thinking man, would wish to make any further trial of fortune ;
tgt_text.6771: since even Cato and Scipio, although they fought in defence of the liberty of Rome, were blamed for having wasted the lives of many brave men in Africa, by not yielding to Cæsar immediately after the battle of Pharsalia.
tgt_text.6772: All men, he urged, are equally liable to the caprices of fortune;
tgt_text.6773: but they have the advan­ tage, even when defeated, of being able to form wise resolu­ tions.
tgt_text.6774: By this reasoning Celsus convinced the generals:
tgt_text.6775: and when, on trying the temper of the soldiers, they found them desirous of peace, and Titianus himself bade them begin negotiations for agreement, Celsus and Gallus determined to go and discuss the matter with Cæcina and Valens.
tgt_text.6776: On their way they were met by some centurions, who informed them that Vitellius's army was already advancing, and that they had been sent on before by their generals to arrange terms of peace.
tgt_text.6777: Celsus spoke with approval of their mission, and bade them return and conduct him to Cæcina.
tgt_text.6778: It happened that when they drew near the army, Celsus was like to have lost his life:
tgt_text.6779: for the cavalry who formed the advance guard were the same who had been de­ feated in the ambuscade, and when they saw Celsus ap­ proaching, they set up a shout of rage and rode towards him.
tgt_text.6780: However the centurions stood before Celsus and kept them back;
tgt_text.6781: and as the other officers called to them to spare him Cæcina perceived that some disturbance was taking place and rode up.
tgt_text.6782: He quickly repressed the disorderly move­ ment of the cavalry, greeted Celsus affectionately, and proceeded with him to Bedriacum.
tgt_text.6783: Meanwhile Titianus had repented of having sent the embassy.
tgt_text.6784: He manned the walls of the camp with those soldiers who had recovered their spirits, and was encouraging the rest to fight.
tgt_text.6785: How­ ever, when Cæcina rode up and held out his hand no one resisted him, but some of the soldiers greeted his troops from the walls, and others opened the gates, came out and mingled with the new-comers.
tgt_text.6786: No violence was done to any one, but they all fraternised and shook each other by the hand, swore fealty to Vitellius and joined his army.
tgt_text.6788: The above is the account which most eye-witnesses give of the battle, though they themselves admit that they do not know all the details of it because of the confusion which prevailed and the irregularity of the ground.
tgt_text.6789: Some time afterwards when I was journeying across the battle­ field, Mestrius Florus, a man of consular rank, who had fought under Otho not from choice but from necessity, showed me an ancient temple, and related that after the battle he came there and saw so huge a pile of corpses, that those on the top were level with the pinnacles of the roof.
tgt_text.6790: He said that he could not discover himself or learn from any one else the cause of this heap ;
tgt_text.6791: for though a greater slaughter of the vanquished is made in civil wars than in any others, because no quarter is given, as no use can be made of prisoners, yet it was hard to imagine how such a mass of carcasses came to be piled together on that spot.
tgt_text.6793: Otho, as is usual in such cases, first heard only confused rumours of how the battle went.
tgt_text.6794: When how­ ever wounded men came from the scene of action bringing the news of the defeat, not only his friends, as might be expected, bade him keep up his spirits and not despair, but his soldiers were wonderfully affected.
tgt_text.6795: None of them left him, or deserted to the enemy, and no one consulted his own safety when his chief despaired of his.
tgt_text.6796: All of them alike repaired to his quarters, and called him their emperor.
tgt_text.6797: When he came out to them, they fell at his feet and caught hold of his hands with shouts, and prayers, and tears, beseeching him not to desert them, or betray them to the enemy, but to make use of them to fight for him, body and soul, until their last breath.
tgt_text.6798: While all besought him thus, one of the common soldiers drew his sword, and crying, “ Cæsar, this is what we are all prepared to do for you," stabbed himself.
tgt_text.6799: Otho, unmoved by any of these entreaties, gazed round upon them all with a calm and composed countenance, and said:
tgt_text.6800: " My comrades, your noble conduct and your loyal devotion make this a happier day to me than that on which you elected me your emperor.
tgt_text.6801: Yet do not deprive me of the etill greater happiness of dying for so many and such noble friends.
tgt_text.6802: If I am worthy to be an emperor of Rome, I ought not to grudge my life to my country.
tgt_text.6803: I am aware that our enemy's victory is not decisive or crushing.
tgt_text.6804: News has reached me that the Mcesian legions have already reached the Adriatic, and are not many days' march distant.
tgt_text.6805: Asia, Syria, Egypt, and the army en­ gaged with the Jews are all on our side, while we have in our power both the senate, and the wives and children of our enemy.
tgt_text.6806: But we are not defending Italy from Hannibal, or Pyrrhus, or the Cimbri, but Romans are fighting against Romans, and our native land will suffer equally whichever side is victorious, for she must lose what the conqueror gains.
tgt_text.6807: Believe me, I pray you, that it is more to my honour to die than to reign:
tgt_text.6808: for I cannot imagine that if victorious I could do anything which would benefit the Romans so much as I can by giving my life to obtain peace and concord, and to save Italy from seeing another day such as this.
tgt_text.6810: After speaking thus, he tore himself away from the soldiers, who tried to hold him back and bade him take courage.
tgt_text.6811: He ordered his friends and such senators as were present to leave his camp:
tgt_text.6812: and to those who were not present he sent similar orders, and also rescripts tc the magistrates of the cities through which they would have to pass, that they might accomplish their journey * with honour and in safety.
tgt_text.6813: He next sent for his nephew Cocceius, who was still a youth, and bade him be of good cheer and not fear Vitellius, whose mother, children, and wife he himself had protected as carefully as if they had been members of his own family.
tgt_text.6814: He had wished, he said, to adopt the boy as his heir, but had put off doing so till the end of the war, meaning to make him his colleague if he succeeded, but not wishing to involve him in his own destruction if he failed.
tgt_text.6816: My last charge to you," he continued, “ is that you neither forget altogether nor yet remember too well that you have had a Cæsar for your uncle."
tgt_text.6817: Shortly after this interview Otho heard a shouting and disturbance outside his quarters ;
tgt_text.6818: for the senators were preparing to depart, and the soldiers were threatening to murder them if they did so, and reproached them with deserting their emperor.
tgt_text.6819: Otho, who feared for their lives, now came out a second time, no longer in a mild and supplicatory manner, but, frowning savagely, he cast so terrible a look upon the most turbulent of the rioters that they shrank away terrified and abashed.
tgt_text.6821: Towards evening he became thirsty, and drank a little water:
tgt_text.6822: after which he spent a long time in ex­ amining the blades of two swords.
tgt_text.6823: At last he rejected one of them, and hid the other in his clothes.
tgt_text.6824: He now called together his servants, and distributed his money amongst them, not recklessly, as though he were dealing with property not his own, but giving them each various sums, carefully apportioned according to each man's deserts.
tgt_text.6825: When he sent them away he rested for the remainder of the night, and those about his bed-chamber noticed how soundly he slept.
tgt_text.6826: At daybreak he called to a freedman who had been entrusted with the management of the de­ parture of the senators, and ordered him to learn what had happened to them.
tgt_text.6827: When he was told that they had left the camp, and had received every attention they could wish, he said, " Go now, and show yourself to the soldiers unless you wish to perish miserably at their hands;
tgt_text.6828: for they will suspect you of having assisted me to die."
tgt_text.6829: When this man was gone, Otho held the sword upright with both his hands and fell upon it, dying with only one groan, which apprised those without of his fate.
tgt_text.6830: The wailing of his slaves was taken up by the whole of the camp and city.
tgt_text.6831: The soldiers noisily forced their way into his quarters and lamented over him with bitter grief, re­ preaching themselves for not having guarded their emperor, and prevented his dying for them.
tgt_text.6832: None of Otho's body­ guard deserted him, although the enemy was drawing near, but after laying out his body, and erecting a funeral pile, they bore him to it, armed at all points;
tgt_text.6833: and happy was the man who could find a place among the bearers.
tgt_text.6834: Of the rest, some kissed his wounds, some pressed his hands, and some, who could not come near him, knelt as his body passed by them.
tgt_text.6835: Some, who had received no especial favours from Otho, and had nothing to fear from his suc­ cessor, slew themselves after they had applied the torch to his funeral pile.
tgt_text.6836: It seems, indeed, that no king or despot ever was possessed with so frantic a desire to rule, as these men had to be ruled by Otho and to serve him ;
tgt_text.6837: for their love for him did not cease with his life, but remained im­ planted in their breasts, causing them to regard Vitellius with the bitterest hatred.
tgt_text.6838: Of what followed from this I shall give an account in its proper place.
tgt_text.6840: After the remains of Otho were buried they erected over him a tomb which could offend no one either by its size or by the pomp of its inscription.
tgt_text.6841: When I was at Brixellum I myself saw a small monument on which was written in the Latin language "
tgt_text.6842: In memory of Marcus Otho.”Otho died in his thirty-seventh year, after a reign of three months.
tgt_text.6843: Many good men, though they blamed his life, yet could not refrain from admiring his death;
tgt_text.6844: for though his life had been no better than that of Nero, his end was a far nobler one.
tgt_text.6845: When he was dead, Pollio, one of the two prefects, offended the soldiers by requiring them at once to swear fealty to Vitellius.
tgt_text.6846: Some of the senators were still left in Brixellum;
tgt_text.6847: and the soldiers, hearing of this, let them go with the exception of Virginius Rufus, whom they greatly embarrassed by coming to his house under arms, and bidding him either take the command of them or at any rate act as ambassador on their behalf.
tgt_text.6848: Virginius, who had refused the crown when it was offered him by a victorious army, thought that it would be the act of a madman to accept it from a beaten one.
tgt_text.6849: He feared, also, to go as an ambassador to the Germans, who thought that in time post he had forced them to do many things against their will.
tgt_text.6850: Accordingly, he escaped from his house by a back door;
tgt_text.6851: and the soldiers, when they discovered that he was gone, took the oaths to the new emperor.
tgt_text.6852: They were pardoned by him, and were sent to serve with the troops under the command of Cæcina.

tgt_text.6: As it appears to me that the life of Nikias forms a good parallel to that of Crassus, and that the misfortunes of the former in Sicily may be well compared with those of the latter in Parthia, I must beg of my readers to believe that in writing upon a subject which has been described by Thucydides with inimitable grace, clearness, and pathos, I have no ambition to imitate Timæus, who, when writing his history, hoped to surpass Thucydides himself in eloquence, and to show that Philistius was but an ignorant bungler, and so plunges into an account of the speeches and battles of his heroes, proving himself not merely one "
tgt_text.7: Who toils on foot afar Behind the Lydian car," as Pindar has it, but altogether unfit for the office of historian, and, in the words of Diphilus, "Dull-witted, with Sicilian fat for brains." lie often seeks to shelter himself behind the opinions of Xenarchus, as when he tells us that the Athenians thought it a bad omen that the general whose name was Victory refused to command the expedition to Sicily;
tgt_text.8: and when he says that by the mutilation of the Hermæ the gods signified that the Athenians would suffer their chief disasters at the hands of Hermokratcs the son of Hermon;
tgt_text.9: or, again, when he observes that Herakles might be expected to take the side of the Syracusans because of Proserpine, the daughter of Demeter, who gave him tho dog Kerberus, and to be angry with the Athenians because they protected the people of Egesta, who were descended from the Trojans, whereas he had been wronged by Laomedon, king of Troy, and had destroyed that city.
tgt_text.10: Timæus was probably led to write, this sort of nonsense by the same critical literary spirit which led him to correct the style of Philistius, and to find fault with that of Aristotle and Plato.
tgt_text.11: Mv own opinion is that to pay too much attention to mere style and to endeavour to surpass that of other writers, is both trifling and pedantic, while any attempt to reproduce that of the unapproachable masterpieces of antiquity springs from a want of power to appreciate their real value.
tgt_text.12: With regard, then, to the actions of Nikias described by Thucydides and Philistius, more especially those which illustrate his true character, having been performed under the stress of terrible disasters, I shall briefly re­ capitulate them, lest I be thought a careless biographer, adding to them whatever scattered notices I have been able to collect from the writings of other historians and from public documents and inscriptions;
tgt_text.13: and of these latter I shall quote only those which enable us to judge what manner of man he was.
tgt_text.15: The first thing to be noted in describing Nikias is the saying of Aristotle, that there had been in Athens three citizens of great ability and patriotism, namely, Nikias, the son of Nikeratus, Thucydides, the son of Melesias, and Theramenes, the son of Hagnon;
tgt_text.16: though the latter was not equal to the two former, but was re­ proached with being a foreigner from the island of Keos;
tgt_text.17: and, also, because he was not a stable politician but always inclined to change sides, he was nicknamed Kothornos, which means a large boot which will fit either leg.
tgt_text.18: Of these three statesmen the eldest was Thucydides, who was the leader of the conservative opposition to Perikles;
tgt_text.19: while Nikias, who was a younger man, rose to a certain eminence during the life of Perikles, as he acted as his colleague in the command of a military force, and also filled the office of archon.
tgt_text.20: On the death of Perikles, Nikias at once became the foremost man in Athens, chiefly by the favour of the rich and noble, who wished to make use of him to check the plebeian insolence of Kleon ;
tgt_text.21: yet Nikias had the good-will of the common people, and they were eager to further his interests.
tgt_text.22: Kleon, indeed, became very powerful by caressing the people and giving them opportunities for earning money from the State, but in spite of this, many of the lower classes whose favour he especially strove to obtain, became disgusted with his greed and insolence, and preferred to attach themselves to Nikias.
tgt_text.23: Indeed, there was nothing harsh or overbearing in the pride of Nikias, which arose chiefly from his fear of being thought to be currying favour with the people.
tgt_text.24: By nature he was downhearted and prone to despair, but in war these qualities were concealed by his invariable success in whatever enterprise he undertook;
tgt_text.25: while in political life his retiring manner and his dread of the vulgar demagogues, by whom he was easily put out of countenance, added to his popularity;
tgt_text.26: for the people fear those who treat them with haughtiness, and favour those who respect and fear them.
tgt_text.27: The reason of this is that the greatest honour which the populace can receive from a great man is not to be treated with contempt by him.
tgt_text.29: Perikles, indeed, used to govern Athens by sheer force of character and eloquence, and required no tricks of manner or plausible speeches to gain him credit with the populace;
tgt_text.30: but Nikias had no natural gifts of this sort, and owed his position merely to his wealth.
tgt_text.31: As ho could not vie with Kleon in the versatile and humorous power of speech by which the latter swayed the Athenian masses, he endeavoured to gain the favour of the people by supplying choruses for the public dramatic performances and instituting athletic sports on a scale of lavish expen­ diture which never before had been equalled by any citizen.
tgt_text.32: The statue of Pallas, erected by him in the Acropolis, is standing at this day, although it has lost the gold with which it was formerly adorned, and also the building which supports the choragic tripods in the temple of Dionysus, for he often gained a victory when choragus, and never was vanquished.
tgt_text.33: It is said that once during the performance of a play at his expense, a slave of his appeared upon the stage habited as Dionysus;
tgt_text.34: a tall and handsome youth, And still beard­ less.
tgt_text.35: The Athenians were charmed with his appearance, and applauded for a long time, at the end of which Nikias rose and said that he did not think it right that one whoso body was thus consecrated to a god should be a slave;
tgt_text.36: and consequently he gave him his freedom.
tgt_text.37: Tradition also tells us how magnificently and decorously ho arranged the procession at Delos.
tgt_text.38: In former times the choruses sent by the cities of Ionia to sing to the glory of the god used to sail up to the island in a disorderly fashion, and were at once met by a rude mob, who called upon them to sing, so that they disembarked in a hurry, huddling on their garlands and robes with unseemly haste and confusion.
tgt_text.39: Nikias disembarked with his chorus upon the little island of Rhenea close by, with all their vestments and holy things, and then during the night bridged the strait -which is very narrow-with a bridge of boats which he had had made at Athens expressly, which was beautifully ornamented with gilding and rich tapestry.
tgt_text.40: Next morning at daybreak, he led the procession to the god over this bridge, with his chorus very richly dressed, and singing as they passed over the strait.
tgt_text.41: After the sacrifice, the public games, and the banquet, he set up the brazen palm-tree as an offering to the god, and also set apart an estate which he had bought for ten thousand drachmas, as sacred to the god.
tgt_text.42: With the revenues of this land the people of Delos were to offer sacrifice and to provide themselves with a feast, and were to pray the gods to bestow blessings on Nikias.
tgt_text.43: All these injunctions to the people of Delos were inscribed upon a pillar which which he left there to guard his bequest.
tgt_text.44: The palm-tree was afterwards overturned by a high wind, and in its fall destroyed the great statue which had been set up by the people of Naxos.
tgt_text.46: These acts of Nikias may have been prompted by ambition and desire for display, but when viewed in con­ nection with his superstitious character they seem moro probably to have been the outcome of his devotional feelings;
tgt_text.47: for we are told by Thucydides that he was one who stood greatly in awe of the gods, and was wholly devoted to religion.
tgt_text.48: In one of the dialogues of Pasiphon, we read that he offered sacrifice daily, and that he kept a soothsayer in his house, whom he pretended to consult upon affairs of state, but really sought his allvice about his own private concerns, especially about his silver mines.
tgt_text.49: He had extensive mines at Laurium, the working of which afforded him very largo profits, but yet was attended with great risks.
tgt_text.50: He maintained a largo body of slaves at the works;
tgt_text.51: and most of his property consisted of tho silver produced by them.
tgt_text.52: For this reason lie was surrounded by hangers-on, and persons who endeavoured to obtain a share of his wealth, and lie gave money to all alike, both to those who might do him harm, and to those who really deserved his liberality, for he gave to bad men through fear, and to good men through good nature.
tgt_text.53: Wo may find proof of this in the writings of the comic poets.
tgt_text.54: Telekleides, speaking of some informer, says:
tgt_text.55: "Charikles a mina gave him, fearing he might say Charikies himself was born in a suspicious way;
tgt_text.57: Now, what his reasons were I know full well, but will not tell, for he's a trusty fere."
tgt_text.58: Eupolis, too, in his comedy of Marikas has a scene where an informer meets with a poor man who is no politician, and says:
tgt_text.59: "A. Sny where you last with Nikias did meet.
tgt_text.61: Save once I saw him in the street.
tgt_text.62: A. He owns ho saw him.
tgt_text.63: Wherefore should he say lie saw him, if he meant not to betray His crimes?
tgt_text.64: C. My friends, you all perceive the fact, That Nikias is taken in the act.
tgt_text.65: D. Think you, 0 fools, that such a man as he In any wicked act would taken be."
tgt_text.66: Just so docs Kleon threaten him in Aristophanes's play:
tgt_text.67: "The orators I'll silence, and make Nikias afraid."
tgt_text.68: Phrynichus, too, sneers at his cowardice and fear of the popular demagogues, when he says :
tgt_text.70: An honest citizen indeed he was, And not a coward like to Nikias."V. Nikias feared so much to give the mob orators grounds for accusation against him, that he dared not so much as dine with his fellow citizens, and pass his time in their society.
tgt_text.71: Nor did he have any leisure at all for such amusements, but when general, he used to spend the whole day in the War Office, and when the Senate met he would be the first to come to the house and the last to leave it.
tgt_text.72: When there was no public business to be trans­ acted, he was hard to meet with, as he shut himself up in his house and seldom stirred abroad.
tgt_text.73: His friends used to tell those who came to his door that they must pardon him for not receiving them, as he was not at leisure, being engaged on public business of great importance.
tgt_text.74: One Hieron, whom he had brought up in his house and educated, assisted him greatly in throwing this air of mystery and haughty exclusiveness over his life.
tgt_text.75: This man gave out that he was the son of Dionysius, called Chalkus, whose poems are still extant, and who was the leader of the expedition to Italy to found the city of Thurii.
tgt_text.76: Hieron used to keep Nikias suppled with prophetic responses from the soothsayers, and gave oat to the Athe - nians that Nikias was toiling night and day on their behalf, saying that when he was in his bath or at his dinner ho was constantly being interrupted by some important public business or other, so that, said he, " His night's rest is broken by his labours, and his private affairs are neglected through his devotion to those of the public.
tgt_text.77: He has injured his health, and besides losing his fortune, has been deserted by many of his friends on account of his not being able to entertain them and make himself agreeable to them;
tgt_text.78: while other men find in politics a means of ob­ taining both friends and fortune, at the expense of the state."
tgt_text.79: In very truth the life of Nikias was such that he might well apply to himself the words of Agamemnon :
tgt_text.80: "In outward show and stately pomp all others I exceed, And yet the people's underling I am in very deed."
tgt_text.82: Perceiving that the Athenian people were willing enough to make use of the talents of men of ability, and yet ever viewed them with suspicion and checked them when in full career, as we may learn from their condem­ nation of Perikles, their banishment of Damon by ostra­ cism, and their mistrust of Antiphon the Rhamnusian, and especially in their treatment of Paches the conqueror of Lesbos, who while his conduct as general was being enquired into, stabbed himself in the open court—per­ ceiving this, Nikias always avoided, as far as he could, taking the command in any important military expedition.
tgt_text.83: Whenever he was employed as general, he acted with extreme caution, and was usually successful.
tgt_text.84: He was careful to attribute his success, not to any skill or courage of his own, but to fortune, being willing to lessen his glory to avoid the ill-will of mankind.
tgt_text.85: His good fortune was indeed shown in many remarkable instances:
tgt_text.86: for example, he never was present at any of the great defeats sustained by the Athenians at that time, as in Thrace they were defeated by the Greeks of Chalkidike, but on that occasion Kalliades and Xenophon were acting as generals, while the defeat in iEtolia took place when Demosthenes was in command, and at Delium, where a thousand men were slain, they were led by Hippokrates.
tgt_text.87: For the pestilence Perikles was chiefly blamed, because he shut up the country people in the city, where the change of habits and unusual diet produced disease among them.
tgt_text.88: In all these disasters Nikias alone escaped censure:
tgt_text.89: while he achieved several military successes, such as the capture of Kythera, an island conveniently situated off the coast of Laconia, and inhabited by settlers from that country.
tgt_text.90: He also captured several of the re­ volted cities in Thrace, and induced others to return to their allegiance.
tgt_text.91: He shut up the people of Megara in their city, and thereby at once made himself master of the island of Minoa, by means of which he shortly after­ wards captured the port of Nisæa, while he also landed his troops in the Corinthian territory, and beat a Corin­ thian army which marched against him, killing many of them, and amongst others Lykophron their general.
tgt_text.92: On this occasion he accidentally neglected to bury the corpses of two of his own men who had fallen.
tgt_text.93: As soon as he discovered this omission, he at once halted his army, and sent a herald to the enemy to demand the bodies for burial, notwithstanding that by Greek custom the party which after a battle demand a truce for the burial of the dead, are understood thereby to admit that they have been defeated, and it is not thought right for them to erect a trophy in commemoration of their victory;
tgt_text.94: for the victors remain in possession of the field of battle, and of the bodies of the dead, and the vanquished ask for their dead because they are not able to come and take them, Nevertheless, Nikias thought it right to forego all the credit of his victory rather than leave two of his countrymen unburied.
tgt_text.95: He also laid waste the seaboard of Laconia, defeated a Lacedæmonian force which opposed him, and took Thyrea, which was garrisoned by Æginetans, whom he brought prisoners to Athens.
tgt_text.97: Now when Demosthenes threw up a fortification at Pylos, and after the Peloponnesians had attacked him by sea and by land, some four hundred Spartans were left on the island of Sphakteria, the Athenians thought that it was a matter of great importance, as indeed it was, to take them prisoners.
tgt_text.98: Yet, as it proved laborious and difficult to blockade them on the island, because the place was desert and waterless, so that provisions had to be brought from a great distance by sea, which was trouble­ some enough in summer, and would be quite impossible in winter, they began to be weary of the enterprise, and were sorry that they had rejected the proposals for peace which had shortly before been made by the Lacedæmo­ nians.
tgt_text.99: These proposals were rejected chiefly because Kleon opposed them.
tgt_text.100: Kleon's opposition was due to his personal dislike to Nikias;
tgt_text.101: and when he saw him enthu­ siastically exerting himself on behalf of the Lacedæ­ monians, he at once took the other side, and persuaded the people to reject the proffered peace.
tgt_text.102: Now as the blockade dragged on for a long time, and the Athenians learned to what straits their army was reduced, they became angry with Kleon.
tgt_text.103: He threw the blame upon Nikias, asserting that it was through his remissness and want of enterprise that the Spartans still held out, and declaring that, were he himself in chief command they would soon be captured.
tgt_text.104: Upon this the Athenians turned round upon him and said, " Why, then, do not you yourself proceed thither and capture them ?
tgt_text.106: Nikias at once offered to transfer his command to Kleon, and bade him take what troops he thought necessary, and, instead of swaggering at home where there was no danger, go and perform some notable service to the state.
tgt_text.107: At first Kleon was confused by this unexpected turn of tho debate, and declined the command ;
tgt_text.108: but as tho Athenians insisted upon it, and Nikias urged him to do so, he plucked up spirit, accepted the offico of general, and even went so far as to pledge himself within twenty days either to kill the Spartans on the island or to bring them prisoners to Athens.
tgt_text.109: The Athenians were more inclined to laugh at this boast than to believe it;
tgt_text.110: for they were well acquainted with the vainglorious character of tho man, and had often amused themselves at his expense.
tgt_text.111: It is said that once the public assembly met early and sat for a long time waiting for Kleon, who came at last very late with a garland on his head, and begged them to put off their debate till the next day.
tgt_text.112: " To-day," said lie, "I am not at leisure, as I have just offered a sacrifice, and am about to entertain some strangers at dinner."
tgt_text.113: The Athenians laughed at his assurance, and broke up the assembly.
tgt_text.115: However, on this occasion, by good fortune and good generalship, with the help of Demosthenes, lie brought home prisoners all those Spartans who had not fallen in the battle, within the time which he had ap­ pointed.
tgt_text.116: This was a great reproach to Nikias.
tgt_text.117: It seemed worse even than losing his shield in battle that he should through sheer cowardice and fear of failure give up his office of general, and give his personal enemy such an opportunity of exalting himself at his expense, depriving himself voluntarily of his honourable charge.
tgt_text.118: Aristo­ phanes sneers at him in his play of tlio ' Birds,' where he says:
tgt_text.119: "We must not now, like Nikias, delay, And see the time for action pass away.
tgt_text.120: "And again in tho play of the 'Farmers,' where thii dialogue occurs:
tgt_text.121: " A. I want to till my farm.
tgt_text.123: 'Tis you Athenians will not Jet me go;
tgt_text.124: A thousand drachmas I would give, to be From office in the state for ever free.
tgt_text.126: The state will have Two thousand, with what Nikias just gave.
tgt_text.127: "Moreover, Nikias did Athens much harm by permitting Kleon to attain to such a height of power and reputation, which gave him such exaggerated confidence in himself that lie grew quite unmanageable, and caused many terrible disasters, by which Nikias suffered as much as any man.
tgt_text.128: Kleon also was the first to break through the decorum observed by former public speakers, by shout­ ing, throwing back his cloak, slapping his thigh, and walking up and down while speaking, which led to the total disregard of decency and good manners among public speakers, and eventually was the ruin of the state.
tgt_text.130: About this time Alkibiades began to gain credit in Athens as a public speaker, less licentious than Kleon, and like the soil of Egypt described by Homer, which bears ..
tgt_text.131: A mingled crop of good and bad alike..
tgt_text.132: Thus Alkibiades, with immense powers both for good and evil, produced great changes in the affairs of Athens.
tgt_text.133: Nikias, even if he had been freed from the opposition of Kleon, could not now have quietly consolidated the power of the state, for as soon as he had arranged matters in a fair way to produce peace and quiet, Alkibiades, to satisfy his own furious ambition, threw them again into confusion and war.
tgt_text.134: This was brought about by the following cir­ cumstances.
tgt_text.135: The two chief hindrances to peace were Kleon and Brasidas ;
tgt_text.136: as war concealed the baseness of the former, and added to the glory of the latter.
tgt_text.137: Kleon was able to commit many crimes undetected, and Brasidas performed many great exploits while the war lasted;
tgt_text.138: wherefore, when both of these men fell before the walls of Amphipolis, Nikias, perceiving that the Spartans had long been desirous of peace, and that the Athenians no longer hoped to gain anything by continuing the war, and that both parties were weary of it, began to consider how he might reconcile them, and also pacify all the other states of Greece, so as to establish peace upon a durable and prosperous basis.
tgt_text.139: At Athens, the richer classes, the older men, and the country farmers all wished for peace.
tgt_text.140: By constantly arguing with the others he gradually made them less eager for war.
tgt_text.141: and at length was able to intimate to the Spartans that there were good hopes of coming to terms.
tgt_text.142: They willingly believed him because of his high character for probity, and more especially because he had shown great kindness to the Spartan prisoners taken at Pylos.
tgt_text.143: A truce for one year had already been arranged between them, and during this they conversed freely with one another, and, enjoying a life of leisure and freedom from the restraints and alarms of war, began to long for an unbroken period of peace, and to sing:
tgt_text.144: "My spear the spider's home shall be," remembering with pleasure the proverb that in time of peace men are awakened, not by trumpets, but by crow­ ing cocks.
tgt_text.145: They railed at those who said that it was fated that the war should last thrice nine years, and, having thus accustomed themselves to discuss the whole question, they proceeded to make peace, and thought that now they were indeed free from all their troubles.
tgt_text.146: The name of Nikias was now in every man's mouth, and ho was called the favourite of heaven, and the man chosen by the gods for his piety to confer the greatest of blessings upon the Greeks.
tgt_text.147: For they regarded the peace as the work of Nikias, just as the war had been the work of Perikles.
tgt_text.148: The latter, they thought, for no adequate reasons, had involved the Greeks in the greatest miseries, while the former had relieved them of their troubles by persuading them to become friends.
tgt_text.149: For this reason this peace is to this day called the peace of Nikias.X.
tgt_text.150: The terms of the peace were that each party should restore the cities and territory which it had taken, and that it should be determined by lot which side should restore its conquests first.
tgt_text.151: We are told by Theophrastus that Nikias, by means of bribery, arranged that the lot should fall upon the Lacedæmonians to make restitution first.
tgt_text.152: When, however, the Corinthians and Boeotians, dissatisfied with the whole transaction, seemed 1 ikely by their complaints and menaces to rekindle the war, Nikias indiced Athens and Sparta to confirm the peace by enter­ ing upon an alliance, which enabled them to deal with the malcontents with more authority, and give them more confidence in one another.
tgt_text.153: All these transactions greatly displeased Alkibiades, who was naturally disinclined to peace, and who hated the Lacodæmionians because they paid their court to Nikias and disregarded him.
tgt_text.154: For this reason, Alkibiades from the very outset opposed the peace, but ineffectually at first.
tgt_text.155: When, however, ho observed that the Lacedæ­ monians were no longer regarded with favour by the Athenians, and were thought to have wronged them by forming an alliance with the Bœotians, and not restoring to Athens up the cities of Panaktus and Amphipolis, lie seized the opportunity of exciting the people by exag­ gerated accounts of the misdeeds of the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.156: Moreover ho prevailed upon the people of Argos to send ambassadors to Athens to conclude an alliance.
tgt_text.157: As, how­ ever, at the same time ambassadors, with full powers to settle all matters in dispute, came from Lacedæmon, and in a preliminary conference with the Senate were thought to have made very reasonable and just proposals, Alki­ biades, fearing that they might create an equally favour­ able impression when they spoke before the popular assembly, deceived them by solemnly declaring with an oath that he would assist them in every way that lie could, provided that they would deny that they came with full powers to decide, saying that by this means alone they would effect their purpose.
tgt_text.158: The ambassadors were deceived by his protestations, and, forsaking Nikias, relied entirely upon him.
tgt_text.159: Upon this Alkibiades brought them into the public assembly, and there asked them if they came with full powers to treat.
tgt_text.160: When they said that they did not, ho unexpectedly turned round upon them, and calling both the Senate and the people to witness their words, urged them to pay no attention to men who were such evident liars, and who said one thing in one assembly and the opposite in another.
tgt_text.161: The ambassadors, as Alkibiades expected, were thunderstruck, and Nikias could say nothing on their behalf.
tgt_text.162: The people at once called for the ambassadors from Argos to be brought before them, in order to contract an alliance with that city, but an earthquake which was felt at this moment greatly served Nikias's purposo by causing the assembly to break up.
tgt_text.163: With great difficulty, when the debate was resumed on the following day, he prevailed upon the people to break off the negotiations with A,- gos, and to send him as ambassador to Sparta, promising that lie would bring matters to a prosperous issue.
tgt_text.164: Accordingly he proceeded to Sparta, where ho was treated with great respect as a man of eminence and a friend of tlio Lacedæ­ monians, but could effect nothing because of the prepon­ derance of the party which inclined to the Bœotian alliance.
tgt_text.165: lIe was therefore forced to return ingloriously, in great fear of the anger of the Athenians, who had been persuaded by him to deliver up so many and such impor­ tant prisoners to the Lacedæmonians without receiving any equivalent.
tgt_text.166: For tho prisoners taken at Pylos were men of the first families in Sparta, and related to the most powerful statesmen there.
tgt_text.167: The Athenians, however, did not show their dissatisfaction with Nikias by any harsh measures, but they elected Alkibiades general, and they entered into a treaty of alliance with the Argives.
tgt_text.168: and also with the states of Elis and Mantinea, which had revolted from the Lacedæmonians, while they sent out privateers to Pylos to plunder the Lacedæmonian coasts in the neighbourhood of that fortress.
tgt_text.169: These measures soon produced a renewal of the war.
tgt_text.171: As the quarrel between Nikias and Alkibiades had now reached such a pitch, it was decided that the remedy of ostracism must be applied to them.
tgt_text.172: By this from time to time the people of Athens were wont to banish for ten years any citizen whoso renown or wealth rendered him dangerous to the state.
tgt_text.173: Great excitement was caused by this measure, as one or the other must be utterly ruined by its application.
tgt_text.174: The Athenians were disgusted by the licentiousness of Alkibiades, and feared his reckless daring, as has been explained at greater length in his Life, while Nikias was disliked because of his great wealth and his reserved and unpopular mode of life.
tgt_text.175: Moreover he had frequently offended the people by acting in direct opposition to their wishes, forcing them in spite of them­ selves to do what was best for them.

tgt_text.177: " r, and those who wished for war, and on the other the older men and the party of peace, who would be sure to vote respectively, one for the banishment of Nikias, the other for that of Alkibiades.
tgt_text.179: In revolutions bad men rise to fame, and it appears that the violence of these factions at Athens gave an opportunity for the lowest and basest citizens to gain reputation.
tgt_text.180: Amongst these was one Hyperbolus, of the township of Peirithois, a man of no ability or power, but who owed his elevation to sheer audacity, and whose influence was felt to be a disgrace to Athens.
tgt_text.181: This man, who never dreamed that ostracism would be applied to him, as the pillory would have been more suitable to his deserts, openly showed his delight at the discord between Nikias and Alkibiades, and excited the people to deal severely with them, because he hoped that if one of them were to be banished, he might succeed to his place, and become a match for the one who was left behind.
tgt_text.182: But the parties which supported Nikias and Alkibiades respectively made a secret compact with one another to suppress this villain, and so arranged matters that neither of their leaders, but Hyperbolus himself was banished by ostracism for ten years.
tgt_text.183: This transaction delighted and amused the people for the moment, but they were afterwards grieved that they had abused this safeguard of their constitution by applying it to an unworthy object, as there was a kind of dignity about the punishment which they had inflicted.
tgt_text.184: Ostracism in the case of men like Thucydides and Aristeides, was a punishment, but when applied to men like Hyperbolus, it became an honour and mark of distinction, as though his crimes had put him on a par with the leading spirits of the age.
tgt_text.185: Plato, the comic poet, wrote of him :
tgt_text.186: "Full worthy to be punished though he be, Yet ostracism's not for such as he.
tgt_text.187: "The result was that no one was ever again ostracised at Athens, but Hyperbolus was the last, as Hipparchus of Cholargus, who was some relation to the despot of that name, was the first.
tgt_text.188: Thus the ways of fortune are in­ ecrutable, and beyond our finding out.
tgt_text.189: If Nikias had aade, gone the trial of ostracism with Alkibiades, ho would either have driven him into banishment, and governed Athens well and wisely during his absence, or he would himself have left the city, and avoided the terrible disaster which ended his life, and would have continued to enjoy the reputation of being an excellent general.
tgt_text.190: I am well aware that Theophrastus says that Hyperbolus was ostracised in consequence of a quarrel of Alkibiades with Phæax and not with Nikias;
tgt_text.191: but my account agrees with that given by the best historians.
tgt_text.193: When ambassadors came to Athens from Egesta and Leontini, inviting the Athenians to commence a campaign in Sicily, Nikias opposed the project, but was overruled by Alkibiades and the war party.
tgt_text.194: Before the assembly met to discuss the matter, men's heads were com­ pletely turned with vague hopes of conquest, so that the youths in the gymnasia, and the older men in their places of business or of recreation, did nothing but sketch tho outline of the island of Sicily and of the adjacent seas and continents.
tgt_text.195: They regarded Sicily not so much as a prize to be won, but as a stepping-stone to greater con­ quests, meaning from it to attack Carthage, and make themselves masters of the Mediterranean sea as far as the Columns of Herakles.
tgt_text.196: Public opinion being thus biassed, Nikias could find few to help him in opposing the scheme.
tgt_text.197: The rich feared lest they should be thought to wish to avoid the burden of fitting out ships and the other expen­ sive duties which they would be called upon to fulfil, and disappointed him by remaining silent.
tgt_text.198: Yet Nikias did not relax his exertions, but even after the Athenian people had given their vote for the war, and had elected him to the chief command, with Alkibiades and Lamachus for his colleagues—even then, on the next meeting of the assembly, he made a solemn appeal to them to desist, and at last accused Alkibiades of involving tho city in a terrible war in a remote country merely to serve his own ambition and rapacity.
tgt_text.199: However, he gained nothing by this speech, for the Athenians thought that he would be the best man to command the expedition because of his experience in war, and that his caution would servo as a salutary check upon the rashness of Alkibiades and the easy temper of Lamachus;
tgt_text.200: so that, instead of dissuading them his words rather confirmed them in their intention.
tgt_text.201: For Demostratus, who of all the popular orators was the most eager promoter of the expedition, rose, and said that he would put an end to these excuses of Nikias :
tgt_text.202: and he prevailed upon the people to pass a decree that the generals, both at home and in the field, should be invested with absolute irresponsible power.
tgt_text.204: Yet it is said that the expedition met with great opposition from the priests;
tgt_text.205: but Alkibiades found certain soothsayers devoted to his own interests, and quoted an ancient oracle which foretold that the Athenians should one day win great glory in Sicily.
tgt_text.206: Special messengers also came from the shrine of A minon,* bringing an oracular response to the effect that the Athenians would take all the Syracusans.
tgt_text.207: Those oracles which mado against the project, people dared not mention, for fear of saying words of ill-omen.
tgt_text.208: Yet even the most obvious portents would not turn them from their purpose, such as the mutilation of all the Hermæ, or statues of Hermes, in Athens, in a single night, except only one, which is called the Hermes of Andokides, which was erected by the tribe Ægeis, and stands before the house in which Andokides lived at that time.
tgt_text.209: A man likewise leaped upon the altar of the Twelve Gods, sat astride upon it, and in that posture mutilated himself with a sharp stone.
tgt_text.210: At Delphi too there is a golden statue of Pallas Athene standing upon a brazen palm tree, an offering made by the city of Athens from the spoils taken in the Persian war.
tgt_text.211: This was for many days pecked at by crows, who at last pecked off and cast upon the ground the golden fruit of the palm tree.
tgt_text.212: This was said to be merely a fable invented by the people of Delphi, who were bribed by the Syracusans.
tgt_text.213: Another oracle bade the Athenians bring to Athens the priestess of Athena at Klazomenae,and accordingly they sent for her.
tgt_text.214: Her name happened to be Hesychia, signifying Repose;
tgt_text.215: and this is probably what the oracle meant that the Athenians had better remain quiet.
tgt_text.216: The astronomer, Meton, who was appointed to some office in the army, either because of these adverse omens and prophecies, or because he was convinced that the expedition would mis­ carry, pretended to be mad and to set fire to his house.
tgt_text.217: Some historians relate that he did not feign madness, but that he burned down his house one night, and next morning appeared in the market-place in a miserable plight, and besought his countrymen that, in considera­ tion of the misfortune which had befallen him, they would allow his son, who was about to sail for Sicily in command of a trireme, to remain at home.
tgt_text.218: We are told that Sokrates the philosopher was warned by one of the signs from heaven which he so often received that the expedition would be the ruin of the city.
tgt_text.219: And many were filled with consternation at the time fixed for the departure of the armament.
tgt_text.220: It was during the celebration of the Adonia.
tgt_text.221: or mourning for the death of Adonis, and in all parts of the city were to be seen images of Adonis carried along with funeral rites, and women beating their breasts, so that those who were superstitious enough to notice such matters became alarmed for the fate of the armament, and foretold that it would start forth gloriously, but would wither untimely away.
tgt_text.223: The conduct of Nikias in opposing the war when it was being deliberated upon, and his steadfastness of mind in not being dazzled by the hopes which were enter­ tained of its success, or by the splendid position which it offered himself, deserves the utmost praise;
tgt_text.224: but when, in spite of his exertions, he could not persuade the people to desist from the war, or to remove him from the office of general, into which he was as it were driven by main force, his excessive caution and slowness became very much out of place.
tgt_text.225: His childish regrets, his looking back towards Athens, and his unreasonable delays disheartened his colleagues, and spoiled the effect of the expedition, which ought at once to have proceeded to act with vigour, and put its fortune to the test.
tgt_text.226: But although Lamachus begged him to sail at once to Syracuse and fight a battle as near as possible to the city walls, while Alkibiades urged him to detach the other Sicilian states from their alliance with Syracuse, and then attack that place, ho dispirited his men by refusing to adopt either plan, and proposed to sail quietly along the coast, displaying the fleet and army to the Sicilians, and then, after affording some slight assistance to the people of Egesta, to return home to Athens.
tgt_text.227: Shortly after this, the Athenians sent for Alkibiades to return home for his trial on a charge of treason, and Nikias, who was nominally Lamachus's col­ league, but really absolute, proceeded to waste time in idle negotiations and languid manoeuvres, until his troops had quite lost the high spirits and hopes with which they had arrived at Sicily;
tgt_text.228: while the enemy, who were at first terrified, began to recover their spirits, and despise the Athenians.
tgt_text.229: While Alkibiades was still with them they had sailed to Syracuse with sixty ships, and while the rest remained in line of battle outside, ten of these had entered the harbour to reconnoitre.
tgt_text.230: These ships, approaching the city, made a proclamation by a herald that they were come to restore the people of Leontini to their city, and they also captured a Syracusan vessel, in which they found tables on which were written the names of all the inhabi­ tants of Syracuse, according to their tribes and houses.
tgt_text.231: These tables were kept far away from the city, in the temple of the Olympian Zeus, but at that time the Syra­ cusans had sent for them in order to discover the number of men able to bear arms.
tgt_text.232: These tables were now taken by the Athenians, and carried to their general.
tgt_text.233: When the soothsayers saw this roll of names, they were much alarmed, fearing that this was the fulfilment of the pro­ phecy that the Athenians should capture all the Syra­ cusan 8.
tgt_text.234: However, some declare that the prophecy was really fulfilled when the Athenian Kallippus slew Dion, and captured Syracuse.XV.
tgt_text.235: Shortly after this, Alkibiades left Sicily, and the supreme command devolved upon Nikias.
tgt_text.236: For Lamachus, though a bravo and honest man, and one who always freely risked his life in battle, was but a plain simple man, and was so excessively poor, that whenever he was appointed general he was forced to ask the Athenians to advance him a small sum of money to provide him with clothes and shoes.
tgt_text.237: Now Nikias was excessively haughty, both on account of his great wealth, and his military renown.
tgt_text.238: It is said that once when the generals were debating some question together, Nikias bade Sophokles the pcet give his opinion first, because he was the oldest man present, to which Sophokles answered, “I am the oldest, but you are the chief."
tgt_text.239: Thus when in Sicily he domineered over Lamachus, although the latter was a far abler soldier, and by sailing about the coast at the point furthest removed from the enemy, gave them confi­ dence, which was turned into contempt, when he was repulsed from Hybla, a little fort in the interior.
tgt_text.240: At last he returned to Katana, without having effected anything, except the reduction of Hykkara, a town of the aborigines, not of the Greeks, from which it is said the celebrated courtezan Lais, then a very young girl, was carried away captive and sent to Peloponnesus.
tgt_text.242: As the summer advanced, and Nikias remained inactive, the Syracusans gained so much confidence that they called upon their generals to lead them to the attack of the Athenian position at Katana, since the Athenians did not dare approach Syracuse;
tgt_text.243: while Syracusan horse­ men even went so far as to insult the Athenians in their camp, riding up to ask if they were come to settle as, peaceful citizens in Katana, instead of restoring the Leontines.
tgt_text.244: This unexpected humiliation at length forced Nikias to proceed to Syracuse, and he devised a stratagem by which he was able to approach that city and pitch his camp before it unmolested.
tgt_text.245: He despatched to Syracuse a citizen of Katana, who informed the Syracusans that if they desired to seize the camp and arms of the Athenians, they would only have to appoint a day and to march in force to Katana.
tgt_text.246: Many of the Athenians, he said, spent all their time within the walls of Katana, and it would be easy for the Syracusan party there to close the gates, assail the Athenians within, and set fire to their ships.
tgt_text.247: A numerous body of Kataneans, he added, were eager to co-operate in the plan now proposed.
tgt_text.248: This was by far the ablest piece of strategy accomplished by Nikias during all the time that he remained in Sicily.
tgt_text.249: The Syracusans were induced to march out their entire force, leaving their city with scarcely any defenders.
tgt_text.250: Meanwhile, Nikias sailed round from Katana, took posses­ sion of the harbour, and encamped his forces on the main­ land in a position where he could not be attacked by the enemy's cavalry.
tgt_text.251: Wheu the Syracusan army returned from Katana, he marched out the Athenians and defeated them, but with little loss on their side, as their cavalry covered their retreat.
tgt_text.252: Nikias now broke down the bridges over the river Anapus, which gave occasion to Hermokrates to say, when he was making a speech to encourage the Syracusans, that it was a ridiculous thing for Nikias to try to avoid fighting, as though it were not for the express purpose of fighting that he had been sent thither.
tgt_text.253: But in spite of all that Hermokrates could say, the Syracusans were very much cast down and disheartened.
tgt_text.254: Instead of the fifteen generals who usually commanded their troops they chose three, upon whom they conferred absolute powers, and swore a solemn oath that they would leave them unfettered in the exorcise of those powers.
tgt_text.255: The Athenians were very anxious to occupy the temple of Olympian Zeus, which was near their camp, and full of offerings of gold and silver.
tgt_text.256: Nikias, however, purposely delayed the attack until a force was sent from Syracuse to defend the temple.
tgt_text.257: He thought that if the soldiers did succeed in plundering it, the state would be none the better for it, and he himself would have to bear all the blame of sacrilege.
tgt_text.258: Nikias made no use of his boasted victory, and after a short time drew off his forces to Naxos, where he passed the winter, expending an enormous sum of money for the maintenance of so largo a force, and effecting little or nothing except the reduction of a few disorderly tribes in the interior.
tgt_text.259: The Syracusans now took heart again, marched into the Katancan territory and laid it waste, and attempted to burn the camp of the Athenians.
tgt_text.260: Upon this all men blamed Nikias for deliberating and taking precautions until the time for action was gone by.
tgt_text.261: No one could find any fault with him when he was actually fighting;
tgt_text.262: but though a bold and energetic man in action, he was slow to form plans and begin an enterprise.
tgt_text.264: Thus when he did at length return to Syracuse, he managed the operation so swiftly and so skilfully that he disembarked his troops at Thapsus before the enemy were aware of his approach, took Epipolæ by surprise, took prisoners three hundred of the force of picked men who endeavoured to recapture that fort, and routed the Syracusan cavalry, which had hitherto been supposed to be invincible.
tgt_text.265: Moreover, what chiefly terrified the Sicilians, and seemed wonderful to all Greeks, was the speed with which he built a wall round Syracuse, a city quite as large as Athens itself, but one which is much more difficult to invest completely, because of the sea being so near to it, and the rough ground and marshes by which it is surrounded on the land side.
tgt_text.266: Yet he all but succeeded in accomplishing this feat, although he was not in a con­ dition of body to superintend such works personally, for he suffered greatly from a disease of the kidneys, to which we must attribute whatever was left undone by his army.
tgt_text.267: For my own part I feel great admiration for the diligence and skill of the general, and for the bravery of the soldiers, which enabled them to gain such successes.
tgt_text.268: The poet Euripides, after their defeat and utter overthrow wrote this elegy upon them:
tgt_text.269: “ Eight times they boat the Syracusan host, Before the gods themselves declared them lost.
tgt_text.270: ”Indeed, they beat the Syracusans far more than eight times, before the gods turned against the Athenians and dashed them to the ground when at the height of their pride.
tgt_text.272: Nikias was present, in spite of his sufferings, at most of these actions ;
tgt_text.273: but when his disease grew worse, ho was forced to stay in the camp with a small guard, while Lamachus took the command of the army, and fought a battle with the Syracusans, who were endeavouring to build a counter-wall which would obstruct the Athenians in building their wall of circumvallation.
tgt_text.274: The Athenians were victorious, but followed up their success in such a disorderly manner that Lamachus was left alone and ex­ posed to the attacks of the Syracusan cavalry.
tgt_text.275: He at once challenged their leader, a brave man named Kallimachus, to single combat, and both received and inflicted a mortal wound.
tgt_text.276: His dead body and arms fell into the hands of the Syracusans, who at once charged up to the Athenian walls, where Nikias lay helpless.
tgt_text.277: The extremity of the danger roused him, and he ordered his attendants to set fire to a quantity of timber which had been brought thither to construct military engines, and to some of the engines themselves.
tgt_text.278: This desperate expedient checked the Syra cusans, and saved N ikias and the Athenians ;
tgt_text.279: for the rest of the Syracusan forces on perceiving so great a body of flame returned in haste to their city.
tgt_text.280: This affair left Nikias in sole command, and he had great hopes of taking the place;
tgt_text.281: for many cities in Sicily had formed alliances with him, ships laden with corn kept arriving to supply his camp, and all began to be eager to be on his side, and to share in the fruits of his success.
tgt_text.282: The Syracusans themselves sent to propose terms of peace, for they despaired of being able to defend their city any longer against him.
tgt_text.283: At this time Gylippus too, a Lacedæmonian who was sent to assist them, heard during his voyage that they were completely enclosed and reduced to great straits, but held on his voyage notwith­ standing, in order that even if, as he imagined, all Sicily had fallen into the hands of the Athenians, he might at any rate defend the Greek cities in Italy from sharing its fate.
tgt_text.285: of rumours that the Athe­ nians were carrying all before them, and that the good fortune and skill of their general rendered him invincible.
tgt_text.286: Even Nikias himself was so elated by his apparent good fortune, that he forgot his wonted prudence, and imagining from the secret intelligence which he had from his friends within Syracuse that it was on the point of surrender, neglected Gylippus altogether, and kept so bad a watch at the straits of Messina with his fleet, that Gylippus managed to cross there and land in Sicily.
tgt_text.287: Here he at once proceeded to gather an army together, but in a quarter of the island far away from Syracuse, so that the people of Syracuse knew nothing of his arrival.
tgt_text.288: They even appointed a day for the public assembly to meet and discuss terms of surrender with Nikias, and were about to attend it, as they thought that it would be best for them to come 10 terms before the city was quite surrounded by the wall of the Athenians.

tgt_text.298: When Nikias had likewise brought his army out of their camp, Gylippus halted his men, and sent a herald to offer them an armistice for five days, on condition that they would collect their effects and withdraw from Sicily.
tgt_text.299: Nikias disdained to answer this insulting message;

tgt_text.301: Timæus says that the Sicilian Greeks despised Gylippus for his avaricious and con­ temptible character, and that when they first saw him, they ridiculed his long hair and Spartan cloak.

tgt_text.305: And not only Thucydides, but Philistus, a Syracusan citizen by birth, who was an eyewitness of the whole campaign, tells us that nothing could have been done without Gylippus.
tgt_text.306: In the first battle after his arrival, the Athenians were victorious, and slew some few Syra­ cusans, amongst whom was the Corinthian Gongylus, but on the following day Gylippus displayed the qualities of a true general.

tgt_text.309: And now the Syracusans, taking fresh courage, began to man their ships of war, and to cut off the stragglers with their cavalry.
tgt_text.310: Gylippus personally visited many of the Greek cities in Sicily, all of whom eagerly promised their aid, and furnished him with troops;
tgt_text.311: so that Nikias, perceiving that ho was losing ground, relapsed into his former desponding condition, and wrote a despatch to Athens, bidding the people cither send out another armament, or let the one now in Sicily return to Athens, and especially beseeching them to relieve him from his command, for which he was incapacitated by disease.
tgt_text.313: The Athenians had long before proposed to send out a reinforcement to the army in Sicily, but as all had gone on prosperously, the enemies of Nikias had contrived to put it off.
tgt_text.314: Now, however, they were eager to send him assistance.
tgt_text.315: It was arranged that Demosthenes should employ himself actively in getting ready a large force, to go to reinforce Nikias in the early spring, while Eurymedon, although it was winter, started immediately with a sup­ ply of money, and with a decree naming Euthydemus and Menander, officers already serving in his army, to be joint commanders along with him.
tgt_text.316: Meanwhile, Nikias was suddenly attacked by the Syracusans both by sea and land.
tgt_text.317: His ships were at first thrown into confusion, but rallied and s ank many of the enemy, or forced them to run on shlore;
tgt_text.318: but on land Gylippus managed at the same time to surprise the fort of Plemmyrium, where there was a magazine of naval stores and war material of all kinds.
tgt_text.319: A considerable number of the garrison, also, were either slain or taken prisoners;
tgt_text.320: but the most serious result was the stoppage of Nikias's supplies, which heretofore had been easily and quickly brought through the Great Harbour, while it remained in the hands of the Athenians, but which now could not reach his camp by sea without a convoy and a battle..
tgt_text.321: Moreover, the Syracusan fleet had not been defeated by any superiority of force of the Athenian, but by the disorder into which it had been thrown by pursuing the enemy.
tgt_text.322: They therefore determined to renew the conflict with better success.
tgt_text.323: Nikias, on his part, was unwilling to fight a second time, thinking it was folly to fight with a diminished and disheartened force when ho knew that Demosthenes was hurrying to his aid with a large and unbroken armament.
tgt_text.324: However, Menander and Euthydemus, the newly-elected generals, were eager to distinguish themselves by per­ forming some brilliant action before the arrival of Demos­ thenes, and to eclipse the fame of Nikias himself.
tgt_text.325: The pretext they used was the glory of Athens, which they said would be dishonoured fur ever if they should now appear afraid to accept the Syracusans' ofer of battle.
